text:
I have one thing that I do every time I cook salmon.  I always make a little foil packet for each fillet and close it up, leaving a little room for air to circulate inside.  If you bake the foil packets on a cookie sheet at 425 for about 15 minutes (slightly longer depending on number of fillets), the salmon cooks to perfection every time!  This is a great recipe to use when preparing salmon in foil packets... it poaches gently in its on juices and always comes out so tender and delicious!

text:
My husband really liked this one. I used 1/3 c. lemon juice and 1/4 tsp. black pepper instead of the lemon pepper. I cut the soy sauce to 1/4 c. to lesson the salt flavor and used only 1 T. olive oil to cut calories. I also sprayed the grill plate with olive oil to keep the salmon from sticking.  Turned out wonderfully.

text:
FANTASTIC! We live in Alaska, and have lots of salmon to eat.  We are always looking for the next great Salmon Recipe.  This one is now our favorite.  Try it, you WILL like it.  My only suggestion is to grill the fish, flesh side down first (facing the hot coals).  This allows the brown sugar to glaze the fish and seal in the moisture.  Then after about 7 minutes, flip the fish over with the skin side down facing the hot coals.  Don't worry about sticking to the grill, the oil in the recipe help to make this not a problem.  Enjoy....Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Excellent recipe.  Be sure to use plain Lemon Pepper and not Lemon Pepper Seasoning Salt (you will oversalt if you do).  If grilling is rained out, this can be baked in a 450 degree oven for 12 minutes, and then broiled for 5 minutes.  The soy sauce and brown sugar blend wonderfully with the salmon flavor.

text:
YUM! This is one of the best marinades I have tasted for salmon! I'd rather stay home and make this than pay for salmon at a restaurant with this recipe! The longer you marinate it - the better. I tried grilling this on a bbq - and it came out very good but didn't hold the seasoning in well (even though I wrapped it in foil). The second time, I wrapped it in foil again and broiled it in the oven - and the marinade really stuck. I use both the lemon pepper seasoning AND fresh lemon juice. I will make this recipe over and over again - especially since I live in the great Northwest where salmon is abundant. I think this would taste good with other types of fish also.

text:
Must agree.  I have used this recipe for years and have a tip for the grillers.  Place the salmon side, skin side down, on aluminun foil.  Grill for 8 minutes on medium heat.  When it's time to turn, grab a long edge of the foil, sliding it off the fire and flip the fish gently onto the hot part of the grill.  Gently remove the foil, and, viola, the skin comes right off.  Brush on some more marinade at this point.  Cover the grill and cook 7 more minutes.  Mmmmmmm....

text:
I made a variation.  I used honey crystals rather than brown sugar (that's what I had on hand).  In addition, I sprinkled the salt and lemon pepper seasoning on the fish.  Finally, I cooked it in a hot skillet on top of the stove with the remainder of the marinade from the bag plus a little water.  By the time the marinade had reduced the fish was tender and flaky and among the tastiest dishes I have ever made.  A very forgiving recipe that really tastes great.

My 4-year old begs me to make this! I followed the advice of another reviewer and usually bake this in a 450 degree oven for 12 minutes and broil for 5 minutes. I also transfer the marinade to a saucepan to make a yummy gravy by adding 1 T. of corn starch and bringing to a boil. Serve with rice for an absolutely super meal!

text:
I used ¼ cup of pure maple syrup in lieu of the brown sugar. My choice of soy sauce was "low sodium".  Added a dash of cayenne pepper (ground chili) to up its tanginess index and rubbed the fish down with all the ingredients incl. the oil. Skipped the lemon pepper and the salt.  Baked in an open, lightly oiled Pyrex dish at 450ºF (10 min. per inch of thickness).  Even without marinating this is a superb dish, a keeper; thanks!

text:
I used a frozen fillet of salmon and baked it in foil.  I sprinkled brown sugar, garlic powder, lemon pepper and salt on the bottom and then put the fillet down.  I pushed the sides of the foil up and sprinkled the seasonings on again and then mixed the soy sauce, water & olive oil and poured it on top and sealed it in.  I cooked it on a baking sheet in the foil at 400 degrees for 20 minutes.  It was moist and delicious!!!

text:
I've made this salmon twice, never altering the recipe and both times it was FANTASTIC!  I did follow the recommendation of another reviewer and grilled it fleshside down first (skin up) and this creates a nice carmalization of the marinade.  When done the meat slid right off the skin.  

The first time I made this, I only marinated it for the minimum of two hours, and it was really good.  The second time I marinated the salmon all day and it was even better!  

A must add to the salmon recipes!

text:
I have made this salmon recipe - exactly as written here - for family (both immediate and extended) and for friends... dozens of times over the past several years.  I will never... I repeat NEVER... make salmon with any other recipe other than this one.  So simple, yet so delicious.  My two sons ask me to make it for them all the time; I would, except buying quality salmon isn't inexpensive.  I have found that our local Costco has some of the freshest salmon available here in the desert southwest... plus, I like that their salmon comes skinless.  (Just a matter of taste, but I'm not a big fan of skin on fish of any kind.).  UPDATE:  11/1/14:  In my opinion, this Is THE best recipe on AR!

text:
This marinade was absolutely delicious!  I actually baked 6 oz. salmon filets, so I made some modifications.  Added a couple splashes of lemon juice to the mixture, instead of seasoning the filets directly with lemon pepper.  I also used jarred minced garlic to taste.  Let the filets marinate for two hours, then wrapped them along with the all of the juice in tin foil and baked on 375 for 35 minutes.  Outstanding!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first seasoned the salmon portions with salt, garlic podwer, freshly squeezed lemon juice and subsituted the Lemon peper with Club's House Lemon & Herb Mix (which contains onions, parsely, pepper, lemon shavings, etc.)

I then marinated the portions for 3-4 hours (frequently stirring up the sauce) A tip, do NOT FORGET TO ADD SALT. I tested a portion without and the salt adds to the sweet & salty factor even with the soy sauce.

I then wrapped the portion in foil underneath a bed of circular cut zucchini and lemon slices and baked for 10 minutes under 350.

THIS WAS FANTASTIC! Paired it with some parma sprinkled asparagus and rizotto mozza/basil balls!

text:
This almost got a 4 star rating but I'm giving it a five because it WAS very good.  Technique in grilling has something to do with how it tastes in the end.  If you don't get it crunchy, with the sauce carmelized, the taste is not the same.  (Some fillets were and some weren't... still learning how to grill it effectively).

I get similar (tastier) results when I marinate salmon in Yoshida's Gourmet sauce so I may just do that next time because it's easier and quicker.  But if I run out of Yoshida sauce, this is a great marinade from scratch for salmon.

The next day we had the leftover salmon with pasta and alfredo sauce... yum.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2006-11-24T10:36:34.41

text:
This marinade is a dominant flavor, and goes toe-to-toe with flavorful salmon pretty well; with any other kind of fish, it would be a one-note dish. This recipe is ideal if your audience includes folks who don't like salmon -- the taste of the salmon is still there, but muted. However, if you're serving only people who love salmon, find a different recipe that will let the salmon shine.

PHENOMENAL marinade.  I also baked it for 20 minutes in foil at 425 instead of grilling, the broiled a couple of minutes to brown.  So moist and flavorful.  Don't throw out the extra marinade! None
text:
This is the most amazing recipe for salmon I have ever had.  This recipe beats out any fish I have had at any restaurant.  My family likes it as much as I do.  I make no changes to the recipe other than the initial cooking.  If the salmon has skin, I cook it on aluminum foil on the grill skin side down in the marinade for 5 minutes.  The skin will stick to the aluminum foil when ready and remove the skin for you.  I just use a spatula and flip it right onto the grill.  I like to cook on high heat so the brown sugar caramelizes and the salmon is still moist.  Thanks for the great recipe!

So simple and delicious!  As others suggested, I replaced the lemon pepper with fresh lemon juice/ground pepper and used olive oil instead of veg. oil. The water helps cut the soy sauce's saltiness. Also added mirin to the marinade. Baked at 425 degrees uncovered for 6 minutes, broiled 1.5 minutes. I used coho salmon - adjust bake time if using less lean cut of salmon (i.e. Alaskan).

text:
This was an excellent recipe. The longer you allow the salmon to marinate, the better it will taste. I let it marinate for 2 hours the first time, and then overnight the second time. While both times the salmon was delicious, it's just better if you leave it to marinate over night. The salmon will take about 7-9 minutes on a forman grill - you will know it's down when you pick the salmon up off the grill, and the skin immediatley falls off/separates from the salmon. This is a quick and easy recipe. I highly recommend you make it with a cucumber salad on the salad or rice pilaf - a great combo.

text:
I really like this recipe - I already have been using it for a variety of meats on the grill. i'M giving it 5 stars even though I made quite a few changes, just because its a good starting point for your own additions. I added lemon zest and some lemon juice to the marinade, as well as one tsp of sesame oil, minced garlic and finely grated ginger. I used spring salmon fillets and marinated for 6 hours in the fridge, and then baked the fish in a hot over, in a foil wrapped dish. I also didn't drain the marinade, nothing wrong with pouring a bit in the baking dish to give it moisture. It really came out moist and flavourful.

text:
We LOVED this recipe!  It was super easy and fast.  I did not marinade the salmon for 2 hours because I did not want the fish to get too soggy.  I only let it sit for about 30 minutes and then basted some reserve marinade 1/2 through grilling.  The fish does not need to be flipped on the grill.  Skin side down for 6-8 minutes on medium high does it! Serve this with some grilled, lemon-garlic asparagus and you have a quick, tasty healthy meal!

country:
None
text:
We enjoyed this recipe, and will use it again.  Living in the NW, we have frequent access to fresh salmon.  Filets are thin, they really don't need to be turned, to cook completely.  We fold foil into a the shape of a jelly roll pan, put the fish on the foil, and the foil on a biscuit pan.  We use the biscuit pan as a big spatulla to slide the foil and fish on and off the grill. We usually cook fillets 6-9 min, or until the fish flakes easily.  The foil allows the fish to "cook" in the marinade.  Wouldn't change anything else...Loved it!  Thanks....

Im sure I'm the only 1 star rater but I'm not going to star something I can't stomach.

text:
I love salmon .... wife, not so much. I have a recipe she likes so I made two versions -- her's and this one (for me). The only thing I added was a small sprinkle of cayenne just before baking. I offered her some of mine .... she tried it ..... and ... verdict was BETTER than her past "acceptable" recipe!!! So ... this recipe works for people who LIKE salmon AND those who do not!!! I followed this recipe exactly, except for the light sprinkling of cayenne and it was really good. I baked mine for 15 minutes at 400 then on broil for 5 minutes. I use a small cast iron pan for all of my baked fish ..... thank you for a new and wonderful recipe!!! CHEERS!!!

I made 1 filet on my indoor grill and it was dry.  I made the other 3 filets in the oven as another reviewer suggested and it was perfect!!  It was done at 15 mins on 425 degrees.  I cut down on the oil to 1 Tbs and used lemon juice and pepper instead of lemon pepper.  This salmon is perfect when it comes out and does not need any extra lemon juice.

text:
I have made a version of this recipe and although not exact, same idea so I had to let you know to MAKE THIS DISH!!!  My version includes: 1/2 c chopped green onions, 1/4 c brown sugar, 1/3 c bourbon (or apple juice), 1 clove garlic, 1/3 c soy sauce, 2 T molasses, and 1/3 c Dijon mustard.  Marinate for 8 hours.  It is the best way to prepare salmon, esp for those new to eating fish.  Divine!!!!

None
text:
I have one thing that I do every time I cook salmon. I always make a little foil packet for each fillet and close it up, leaving a little room for air to circulate inside. If you bake the foil packets on a cookie sheet at 425 for about 15 minutes (slightly longer depending on number of fillets), the salmon cooks to perfection every time! This is a great recipe to use when preparing salmon in foil packets... it poaches gently in its on juices and always comes out so tender and delicious!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
BEST salmon recipe we ever ate!!  I use a whole Wild Sockeye Salmon filet (around 1 1/2 pounds) when available.  Used low sodium soy sauce and kept all other ingredients the same.  I imagine the oil could definitely be cut to 1/8 cup.  Spray grill so fish does not stick. Grilled flesh side down for 4 minutes first to get a nice glazed grill mark.  Turned skin side down for another 4 minutes.  DO NOT OVERCOOK WILD SALMON or it will be very dry.  This is the only salmon recipe my family will allow me to make!!  ENJOY!

My second time making this and this time I think it was even better! I baked it for 45 mins @ 400 degrees -- First line a pan with foil, then put in the pieces of salmon and all the left over marinade from the bag. Then pour two small (like the ones you can get for (.89 cents a bag) bags of veggies around the salmon and just stir them into the marinade a little. It came out PERFECT and looked so nice with all the other colors mixed in from the veggies. It was a hit at our table again, and my toddler ate two servings! I really think he thinks it's chicken :-)

text:
We eat a ton of Salmon throughout the winter season and I always use this marinade.  I do substitute a few of the spices and omit the salt based on personal preference but I must also say the original spices are yummy as is.  If interested, my alterations are as follows: 1-1/2 lb. of salmon skin removed, Old Bay Seasoning to taste, dash or two of Cumin, Garlic Powder to taste, 1/3 cup Soy Sauce, 1/3 cup Brown Sugar, 1/3 cup Water, 1/4 cup Extra Virgin Olive Oil.  I make two separate batches of the marinade; one for marinating the fish and the other for basting the fish as I cook it on the grill.  Fish Tip:  If you have picky eaters who don’t care for strong flavored fish I suggest the following:  Soak the fish in Milk for one hour in a zip-lock bag, drain off milk, rinse and marinate as specified.  Thank you for this scrumptious marinade!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified the recipe a bit for speed, but the flavor should be roughly the same, so my rating is based on that.  It's delicious!  I skipped the marinating step since I knew I'd have plenty of sauce for soaking and this was ready in half an hour.  I used 1.5 lbs salmon (2 fillets) with half of the other ingredients as follows:

1. In a small bowl, mix 1.5 tbsp lemon juice, 1/8 tsp pepper, a pinch of garlic powder, 8 tsp low sodium soy sauce, 8 tsp brown sugar, 2 tbsp water, and 2 tbsp olive oil.

2. Rip a piece of aluminum foil large enough to wrap around a fillet roughly 1.5 to 2 times.  Place the fillet on one half facedown, pour half the sauce over it, and then fold the foil over it.  Pinch the very edges together, folding them over twice to make a well-sealed packet with some extra space inside (the packet will puff up a little in the oven).  

3. Place salmon packets in the oven, preheated to 440 degrees.  Bake for 10 minutes, then flip and bake for another 10.  Serve alone or with a side - YUM!

I am trying to get myself to like salmon, so I tried this recipe. It's very teriyaki like. I had a tiny 4 oz piece of salmon so I lightly seasoned it with the lemon pepper and salt, I used fresh garlic and cut the recipe to 2 TBL each of the soy, brown sugar, water and oil then marinaded it overnight in a baggie. I baked it in a foil packet in a 375' convection oven for 20 mins. and served over rice. The marinade was good, couldn't take the lemon pepper and it hid the taste of the salmon (which for me could be a good thing). From everyone else's review this sounds like it's a fave and a big star rating for them. I'm still trying to like salmon though...

userID:

Display Name:

text:
I absolutely agree with the other reviewers out there. This is one of the best marinades for salmon that I have personally tried. I too used the foil packet method (about 20 minutes at 425) and then opened them up and broiled for another 5 minutes to get the marinade to caramelize up a bit and brown the top of the fish. It turned out tender and delicious. Thank you very much for sharing this wonderful recipe.

You know its a good recipe when I review it twice since I accidentally clicked cancel! This pleased me, who HATES salmon, my 1 year old, my 9 year old....AND THE HUBBY. They all went back for more. The baby kept saying "Fish fish MORE good!" I baked it at 450 for 13 minutes. I forgot to marinate so just poured the sauce over the seasoned fillets. I however did NOT add salt to taste as the soy sauce already offers more than enough. This is not a FISHY tasting recipe. It is AMAZING!

Display Name:
Josephine Roeper

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG!!! SO GOOOOOODDDD!!! Didn't have lemon pepper so I used ***I love lemon so this may not work for others*** 2/3 cup lemon juice --- pepper, garlic powder, salt, and onion powder to taste --- 1/3 cup soy sauce --- 2/3 cup brown sugar ***to offset the double lemon juice*** --- 1/3 cup water --- 1/4 cup oil. I marinated for 24 hours in fridge because salmon was in deep freezer. Baked in oven 450 degrees for 12 minutes. Then I broiled for 5 minutes, checked fish, and broiled for another 5 minutes (because I was cooking 7 fillets) in little aluminum foil pouches.

text:
Fantastic!!! Never been a fan of marinating salmon because it is so flavorful. I reluctantly tried this to see if the rest of the famiy would like it. Wife loved it and salmon is one of her least favorite fish. Even the kids (4 & 6) enjoyed it. It has a sweet flavor at first taste, but the marinade does not overpower the fish, and the natural flavor still comes through. An instant family pleaser and keeper.

text:
A really great recipe!!  I prepared this for dinner last evening and we enjoyed it so much. Before reading the reviews of many others, I thought my husband and I were the only 2 people who didn't like salmon.  However this method of preparation has certainly converted us!  I baked the fish at 450 degrees for 15 minutes then broiled it for another 5.   I also thickened the marinade (but with a little corn starch) and added that to the serving plate.  Thank you so much for this recipe...we will be enjoying a lot more salmon and using the same marinade for other seafood.

text:
Really tasty!  A nice change from the ususal lemon/dill salmon.  I have to admit though, that I tweaked the recipe a bit.  I used the lemon pepper, garlic, and salt, cut the soy sauce and brown sugar to 3 tablespoons each, omitted the water and oil, and used 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice instead.  I marinated the fillets in this for four hours then baked it in the oven.  (I didn't drain the marinade.)  Came out wonderful!  A definite keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of our favorite ways to grill salmon. The only thing I do differently is to boil down the marinade after putting the fish on the grill and use it to baste the fish while grilling. It's safe to use after boiling down and creates the most wonderful mahogany glaze on the fish. Try it, you'll love it. Also, I always use a fish basket for grilling to keep the fish from sticking to the grill - so much easier!

text:
Added 1 squeezed lemon, omitted water, used a dash of olive oil (substitution for other oil), omitted salt, doubled marinade, and added fresh ginger. Only marinated long enough to get the oven warmed up and the rice and green beans going. Cooked at 350 until everything else was done (about 20-30 min?), basting a couple times, then broiled for a few minutes while I seasoned the green beans. Really, it didn't take long at all and is superb! No leftovers on the fish. I will be saving the leftover marinade/sauce from the pan to use with the leftover rice when I make fried rice. Will DEFINITELY make again!

text:
Not that another review is needed, but here's my two cents (and if I don't write down what I did, my family will be mad!)  I used all the specified ingredients, sans lemon pepper (sorry, not a fan). I whisked in the juice of half a lemon, a good dose of Penzey's minced garlic and freeze dried shallots, garlic/onion powders, jarred minced garlic (yes, I'm a garlic fanatic!) a couple tablespoons of Thai sweet red chili sauce, a sprinkling a red pepper flakes, a spritz of ground ginger and some freeze-dried chives. Yes, this is more ingredients than the original recipe....who cares, it was perfect for our family and I see this marinade as a regular Friday night rotation this summer. Pierced the salmon fillets using a fork and then seasoned them using fresh lemon juice, sea salt, pepper, and garlic/onion powders. Marinated for about 4 1/2 hours.  Grilled using a foil-lined grill basket for easy cleanup for 7 minutes skin-side down first, then 7 minutes flesh-side up. Perfection!!!! My 5 year-old DD wanted more salmon rather than a chocolate gelato for dessert! Served with a grilled veggie medley (zucchini/squash/Vidalia onions and yellow & red cherry tomatoes) and steamed jasmine rice. Not many dinners get a "5 stars across the board" rating, but this one.....oh yeah, baby.

This is absolute salmon perfection! I sometimes bake this in the oven at 425 degrees for 12 to 18 minutes depending on the thickness of my salmon. It is so moist and delicious. The other day I had some of this marinating (a beautiful, expensive fillet) and got into a car accident. I love to add quite a bit of lemon pepper and garlic powder, the combination of the spiceness and the sweetness is tantalizing. YUM!

text:
The only thing that I would add to this delicious recipe is a tip from the woman who sold me my salmon. I grilled it skin side down first and then slid the fillet off of the skin and flipped the other side back onto the skin that was still on the grill.  I didn't lose any salmon and I was glad I didn't when I tasted it!

text:
I've been using this for years and our family loves it!  I reduce the remaining marinade for a topping, but I'm the only one who uses it.  You don't have to grill it.  You can finish it off in the broiler to brown it, but watch it closely.  Some reviewers said it was too sweet, but that's probably because they didn't add enough salt before marinating.  The only way you won't like this is if you don't like salmon or soy sauce.  Thanks for this recipe!

Great recipe, didn't change a thing and my wife (who is not a seafood fan) loved this.  I have a small 45 degree needle nose plier that I keep in the kitchen utensil drawer that I use to remove the pin bones.  I use a paring knive to depress the flesh and then the needle nose plier to pull out the pin bones.  The combination of no fish bones and great taste did it for the wife.

I haven't tried this recipe but but I have a very simple way to make salmon.  Brush with Mikee brand Sesame Teriyaki Sauce.  Marinate the salmon then put it in a pan and cover the pan with aluminum foil and bake @ 350 for about 20 - 25 minutes or until it's done.  I had it with dried cranberry/pecan cous cous.  I prefer salmon steaks to salmon filets, but it is good with both!  Mikee Sesame Teriyaki Sauce is probably comprised of the same ingredients made in this recipe and it has sesame seeds!  Very easy!

text:
I marinated my salmon for over 7 hours, which still didn't impart as much flavor as I'd hoped! (I did skip the salt though.)  I added dill and more lemon pepper, as well as a topping of a little more brown sugar, and then baked mine in the oven still in the marinade. It was so saturated in juices that it was a little hard to tell when it was done, but it turned out delicious, with a moist texture and sweet top layer from the extra brown sugar.  My hubby still prefers my extra lemony version of salmon, but I loved it!

text:
Wonderful recipe.  I eat salmon all the time and this was a nice twist.  I marinated it in a 13x9 pan with the skin side up for about 3 hours.  Then baked it on a foil-lined cookie sheet, skin side down, at 400 for 20 minutes.  I let it rest for about 5 minutes before serving.  The marinade left a nice carmelized glaze on the top. Excellent!

text:
I've been making this recipe for years, and realized I've never reviewed it.  I almost always make it for company, and am always asked for the recipe or to make it when they come for dinner again!  I have made it both on the grill and in the oven.   When I grill I often use the Reynolds Release foil under the salmon -- it never sticks or chars, but still gets a nice finish.  (It does slide a little when you want to flip it, but it really takes the stress out of grilling fish if you are at all concerned.) Excellent -- I have no need for any other salmon recipe!

All I can say is "WOW". You MUST make this! I don't think I can eat salmon any other way again. It was so simple to prepare too. text:
I didn't think this sounded that great, (soy sauce and sugar?) but because it was on the top 20 recipes I tried it anyway. My boyfriend and I are both very picky about salmon. I will only eat it at one restaurant in our tri-country area. We both just about died when we tasted this. I kept repeating "OH MY GOD" every time I took a bite. One tip - get Alaskan Red King salmon, its very moist. Also, don't get too thick a filet of salmon, it makes it tough to grill it all the way through. You end up leaving it on too long and then it's dry.

FIVE STARS I LOVE THIS RECIPE!!!!!!!!!!!!!

text:
The marinade was very tasty!  I did make a few changes after reading other reviews.  I only used 1/4 cup of soy sauce (the low sodium kind).  I mixed brown sugar and Splenda to make it a little healthier, and I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  I marinated the salmon in a baking dish, skin up, for 8 hours and was disappointed that the salmon did not absorb enough of the flavor of the marinade.  I ended up making another batch of marinade to pour over the cooked salmon, and then it tasted amazing.  I would definitely recommend making some extra marinade or reserving some to pour over the cooked salmon.  Very delicious flavor!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was pretty excited about making this after reading the reviews.  I am a fish lover already, and salmon is an excellent, versatile fish to work with.  My husband is not crazy about fish, but he is getting there, and salmon is one fish he does like.  I thought this recipe was a nice change from my traditional way of preparing salmon. I made it 3 nights ago and my husband still talks about it "Remember that great dinner we had the other night?"  ;)  The things we did differently:  I added 1 tsp. minced garlic to the marinade, and subbed orange juice instead of water, like some other reviewers suggested. I marinated the salmon all day, for about 9 hours, and I think that was fine.  We did grill it, but wrapped in aluminum foil to seal in the flavors instead of laying the fish right on the grill.  I also took the leftover marinade, boiled it to reduce, and added some cornstarch to thicken it, which made an excellent dipping sauce.  We would term this recipe "Teriyaki Salmon" because of the soy sauce flavor...very good.  I will probably use this recipe throughout the summer because of the grill!

This recipe is wonderful! I use it almost once a week. I did find the key is not to marinate for too long. If you do the brown sugar dissolves too much. Also, by adding more brown sugar the fish really is great!

text:
7.6.17  I made this exactly as written and was happy with the way it turned out.  The only thing you’ll have to stay on top of is the cooking time, and that’s dependent upon the thickness of the filets.  We overcooked ours just a little, but it still flaked nicely, and unlike some reviewers, we had no issue with the salmon being bland, being too sweet, being too salty, etc.  Actually, we found the flavor pretty mild and fresh, and when removing the filets from the grill, they just slipped right off of the skin.  I bought fresh wild Alaskan sockeye salmon and cooked it the same day.   We enjoyed this recipe and plan to buy more while the fresh salmon is available (and on sale, too!).

text:
This marinade is SO GOOD! I don't grill my salmon, I bake it. I found a video on this site on how to perfectly bake salmon. You heat your oven to 450. Once preheated you heat a glass or ceramic baking dish with a couple tbls of butter for 5 minutes. Then bake your salmon for 10 minutes per inch of thickness. I always buy the center cut fillets and bake for 10 minutes. I've made this recipe countless times and they always come out perfectly cooked, not over done. What a great recipe for the marinade!!!

text:
This has to be one of my favorite ways to marinate salmon! The pairing of soy sauce with brown sugar gives the fish an added sweet and savory flavor. Salmon comes out so tender and flaky.  I average marinating time for at least 2 hours, but have had it sit for up to 4 before grilling. I have done grilling directly on grate, but I prefer to use a large sheet of foil, sprayed with Pam, and place the foil directly on the grill, less chance of losing any delicious meat to the coals.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly with the exception that I cooked it under the broiler for 5 minutes on each side and I used the marinade to make a sauce to dip the fish in by boiling it with some cornstarch.  I also didn't season the fish with salt since the Lemon Pepper and soy sauce are both very salty.  I only used the lemon pepper, garlic powder and a little onion powder to season the fish and since I only had 3 salmon steaks I decreased my soy sauce and water to 1/4 of a cup each, kept the oil the same and added a little extra brown sugar on top of the 1/4 cup.  This so far has been my favorite salmon recipe that I have found.

text:
I loved this recipe! I'm so glad that I picked this one. I did a few things differently. 
First, I didn't grill it, I baked it. I used sesame oil instead of vegetable oil. I also didn't marinate it because I just found the recipe tonight and I really wanted to make it. For baking, I preheated the oven to 375, I then put a little of the oil and the dry seasonings on the bottom of the pan. Then I placed the fish in the pan, and sprinkled some more of the dry seasonings on top. Then I made the sauce and poured it on top of the fish.

I also made rice as a side to this. The rice and the fish with the sauce was perfect. I will be making this again.

Perfect salmon recipe.  I have been using this recipe at least 2-3 times a month for about a year because my family and I LOVE it. This was really good! I only was able to marinate it for about 45mins, but I flipped a few times while soaking. I also added minced garlic to the marinade. Then I made foil tents (with cracks to breathe), added some marinade and baked at 425 for 15 mins. Then I uncovered and broiled for 5 mins. Turned out really good. My BF loved it, and cleaned his plate. I made with almond rice and broiled veggies. Next time I will add a sprinkle of cayenne to the marinade. Keeper!

This is amazing. With it being November in the upper midwest I decided to skip the grill and bake it. I did everything according to the recipe, until the cooking part. I put a layer of 2 cups frozen green beans in a square casserole dish and laid the fillets on top, pouring the marinade over the fillets. Then baked at 425 for 15 minutes, basted, and baking 10 minutes longer. Amazing dish, the flavors were perfect, and my 3 year old son finished his whole plate in minutes!

text:
Fantastic marinade! Great combination of flavors that really compliment the salmon. I skipped the lemon pepper and salt (husband's high blood pressure) and added some fresh ground black pepper and juice of a small lemon. Also used jared minced garlic and olive oil. As other reviewers mentioned I baked and then broiled it, and also did a reduction on the marinade to serve over the salmon and some rice. The sauce on top was delicious. Can't wait to make this again.

text:
This recipie was sooooo good!  It's always a hit when I make it.  I like to marinate the fish around 6-8 hours.  It doesn't seem to mess with the texture of the fish.  The second time I made this, I added a teaspoon or so of toasted sesame oil which was pretty good.  Note, I would cook the flesh part first on the grill before the skin side so that the skin will keep the fish together as you lift it off the grill.

text:
Wow. This was really tasty! Both my wife and I really enjoyed the flavor. I followed the recipe exactly; but for those of you who thought it was too salty or too bland remember that 3 ingredients are "too taste". For me, I used skinless cuts and prepped a charcoal grill with apple wood chips. I lightly sprinkled each side with salt, but then was slightly more generous with the garlic powder and even more so with the lemon pepper. I rubbed the spices in a little before marinating for a good 2.5+ hours. Great!

country:
None
text:
PRETZEL CRUSTED version!  Remove the salmon from the marinade and bread it with crushed pretzels.  Place it in a cast iron skillet with oil preheated, turning when browned.  Remove salmon at desired doneness and set aside.  Pour marinade into skillet, add one squeezed lemon, and bring to a boil.   The pretzel crumbs that fell off the salmon will thicken the sauce.   Pour over salmon.  This dish was WONDERFUL!

Love this- easy and quick enough for a school night! A few tips of my own: sub 1/4 c honey for the sugar; use fresh lemon juice (2tbs); Omit salt and opt for a clove or two of fresh garlic. I line my grill with foil, grill skin side up first, flip, and then top seared fish with thinly sliced lemon rounds for remainder of cook time. Delish!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salmon recipe is amazing.  Salmon can be so boring.  This recipe is super easy and soooo tasty, you'll think you're in a high-priced restaurant.   My only change: I only cook approximately .75 lbs of salmon at a time and don't adjust the marinade -- recipe suggests 1.5 pounds.  It doesn't over power the salmon and because salmon has such a strong flavor to being with, I like the stronger marinade.    In fact, if I made 1.0 - 1.5 pounds, I'd double the marinade.  Also, winters are too cold to grill, so I have baked these and they work just fine.    Try this recipe!

WOW!!!  The flavor was tremendous.  This is definetly one to keep.  I only made a few changes.  Since I don't keep brown sugar handy, I used molasses crystals (a raw sugar.  I also seared the fish in a saute pan.  When the fish was cooked through, I removed the fish and reduced the sauce. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/160402.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was FANTASTIC! Quite frankly I’m not a fish person at all BUT I tried this recipe and surprisingly, I was able to eat and enjoy it. The simple changes that I made for a quicker meal were in step 1 I squeezed lemon juice from 1 1/2 lemon and used about 2tsp of black pepper instead of lemon pepper to season the fillets. For Step 2 I added an extra 1/3 cup of brown sugar (we love a little extra sweetness) then placed the mixture and fillets in a freezer bag and put that into the freezer for about 40-45 minutes since I didn’t have the extra 2 hours. Instead of using a grill that I don’t have yet I used Elizabeth’s Review/Advice and made “a little foil packet for each fillet and close it up, leaving a little room for air to circulate inside. If you bake the foil packets on a cookie sheet at 425 for about 15 minutes (slightly longer depending on number of fillets)” the salmon did cook to perfection while so tender and marinating in its own juices inside of the foil packets.

text:
I opted to use the bake/broil method since I ran out of propane for my grill. I baked it at 450 for 12 minutes and broiled it for 5 min. It tasted awesome and the only thing I'd recommend when using this method is use lemon juice and pepper to make it not so salty to the taste buds. Other than that the recipe was AWESOME!!! I served it with brown rice, corn (for my picky hubby and son)and brocoli and cheese (for myself).

country:
None
text:
I think salmon is a difficult dish to prepare. I really don't like it with just lemon butter and herbs, so I was thinking this recipe could be a winner and it definitely was.

I was worried that with the lemon pepper seasoning, the fish would be just way too salty, but it wasn't. I only marinated it for 2 hours so next time I hope to marinate for about 4-6. Even so, it was really good.

I served this over the "Indian Style Basmati Rice" recipe from this site. The rice is made with a stick of cinnamon... which I thought really complimented the fish and marinade. 

We didn't have a grill so I put the fillets skin side down on a glass baking dish. Baked at 450 for 15 minutes and broiled for 5-6 minutes.

text:
I LOVE this recipe! I haven't been able to eat or make many fish dishes because my fiance doesn't care for seafood.  But upon his first bite he said, "Wow, I wasn't that hungry but this salmon is making me hungry!" I bought a 1.5lb boneless filet at Costco, used olive oil because I didn't have vegetable oil, and I marinated it overnight. Based off of another review, I put the salmon in foil packets (I cut the filet into 2 because it was really big) and in the oven at 450 for 15 minutes. The salmon was cooked perfectly and it was very moist. I also threw sliced mushrooms, butter, and garlic powder into a separate foil packet and cooked it in the oven with the salmon. Next time I think I'll throw diced tomatoes and onions with the salmon.

text:
WOOO HOOO! Boy did my wife like this! It was raining really hard out last night, so instead of grilling I prepared this inside. I used a whole lemon’s juice and rough ground pepper instead of the lemon-pepper stuff. Also, I simply mixed it into the soy sauce/brown sugar sauce instead of directly to the fish. I placed the fish, with all the sauce, in a Ziploc bag and let it sit in the fridge for 2 hours as recommended, turning it every so often. I then took a glass casserole dish and wiped olive oil on the bottom. I placed the filet, skin side down in the dish. I also poured a little extra sauce over the fish. Baked at 450°F for 12 minutes, then broiled for 10, as suggested in another review, it came out perfect!  I served this with steamed rice and steamed carrots. Mmmmm.. We’ll be eating this again!

text:
This is an excellent salmon marinade! I've made similar marinades before (using maple syrup vs brown sugar) for baking salmon, but somehow this was the best I've ever tasted - perhaps because this was grilled! I followed the advice of 1 T oil and substituted lemon juice and fresh minced garlic for the powders, and marinated in the fridge for 30 hrs. Against all odds (never before grilled fish, and very finicky about salmon), the fillets stayed intact and came out delicious - even better chilled the next day for salads!

Very nice! I ran out of time and ended up marinating them overnight and grilling them the following afternoon. Had a very nice "Japanese-grilled fish" taste. text:
Overall excellent recipe, good taste. Used 2 tbsp lemon pepper and 1/2 tsp garlic salt. As another user suggested, save the marinade for use as a dipping sauce.  Much better this way.  Also, make sure to cook thoroughly to avoid "fishy" taste.  If you're using the George Foreman grill, you'll need to cook longer than the 4 1/2 minute suggested time.  About 8 minutes should be right.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe for salmon marinade of all on this site. We do not like pepper much in our family, so I substituted 2 tblsp. lemon JUICE for it and put the juice in the marinade. I also added 1 tblsp. GINGER to the marinade. What a marvelous taste sensation. I also like the fact that there is a LOT of marinade...most recipes are too skimpy on it. We use a double-sided indoor grill that cooks evertyhing very quickly, so a very deep marinade is needed to retain the flavor. I marinade most of the day prior to dinnertime. Thanks for a great recipe!

userID:
107278
Display Name:
MONDEEP
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with the other posters.  This is a great recipe and if you do it right, it will taste just like what you get at a restaurant. I have never had luck before with grilling salmon, but that has changed after following some tips from the other reviewers. First of all I made the marinade exactly as it's stated in the recipe, although I did not add any additional salt to taste.  I used skin-on wild sockeye salmon, marinated it for two hours and then grilled it on an oiled grate with the flesh side down first, on medium-high heat (gas grill).  After about 7 minutes, it had nice grill marks and I flipped it for another 7 minutes.  While it was grilling, I boiled the marinade and used it as a sauce on top of the salmon when serving.  It was perfect and even my husband who does not like fish and my elementary aged kids loved it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing!  I love fish, but have only ever ruined it when I try cooking it myself, and I've never attempted to grill it.  This recipe turned out perfectly for me on the first attempt!  I didn't have lemon pepper, so just squeezed a lemon and used black pepper.  I love the tinfoil tip I read from a few others: put the skin side down on a piece of tinfoil, carefully flipped the fish off onto the grill, and the skin stuck to the tinfoil.  Voila!  It was like magic; I hate picking fish away from the skin while it's on my plate.  

Highly recommend this recipe, even suitable for amateur fish grillers.  :)

text:
Oh my God this was amazing. I use Tamari instead of Soy Sauce to cut down on gluten (no difference in taste) and I added ginger to the marinade which just made it even more delicious. Recommend spraying the grill with olive oil spray first, then grill flesh-side down first then flip to skin. 7 minutes per side is perfect for medium. We actually got farm-raised instead of wild-caught but we did it at Whole Foods who swear their farm-raised is healthy, non-everythingthat'sbadforyou and hey, it happened to be dollars cheaper. Maybe the best dinner I've made in ages. Served with warm black lentil salad and braised spinach (a la Lidia Bastianich). So healthy, so yummy. Yay!

text:
Omg! We had this tonight and it was AMAZING! My pickest eater husband even loved it and ate an entire piece! 
I made a couple changes from reviews. Added 1/3 c  fresh squeezed lemon juice to the marinade instead of water. Then baked in a foil packet at 425° for 14 min then opened the packet, basted the fish with juices moved to top rack and cooked for additional 3 min. Was perfect!!! (Oh yeah... I slowly poured 1/4 cup of the marinade over the fish before sealing the packet).

text:
Thank you! I've made this twice in 1 month. I've always grilled fish but live in a NYC apt. now without a grill, so I was searching for a recipe to do in the oven & followed Elizabeth's review from 11/9/07. My husband & I split 1 pound of fish, so I scale back on the marinade proportions a bit & substitute with olive oil & lemon juice. I've only had time to marinate for 30 min. in small casserole dish which I then cover in foil to bake (with the marinade) - so easy! Baked for 13 min. at 425, then opened the foil (covering the more done portions) & broiled 2 min. to finish.The sauce carmalizes on top & is so good spooned onto the fish at the table.Thank you!

text:
Simple, tasty, and quick - a winner to add to the regular weeknight rotation!

Made a few modifications:
- marinated for only 20 min (prob better to do for longer, but I was short on time and it still tasted great)
- reduced sugar by half
- instead of grilling, cooked in oven in cast iron skillet (skin side down) at 425 for 14 min, then broiled for 1.5 min. Saved a bit of reserve marinade sauce to sprinkle over top at the end

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this! Made it twice now, and I measured the seasonings: I used 1/4 teaspoon of McCormick's lemon pepper (but you could substitute regular pepper and a bit of salt), 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder.  I used NO salt but added one Tablespoon of lemon juice. The soy sauce makes it salty enough.  I think you could get by with half the entire recipe if you don't have a lot of fish.  Also, I just throw all the ingredients into a ziplock bag, mix and add the salmon pieces.  It was great with less than an hour marinating.  I use two small grill trays from the dollar store, take them outside to spray with olive oil Pam, then sandwich the fish and put on a preheated grill. Makes them easy to turn using oven mitts and they don't stick to the grill. Leftovers were so delicious too, just cold for lunch - yum!  Thank you, Tinamenina!

country:
None
text:
Loved it! I made it twice. The second time I subsituted most of the brown sugar with pure Canadian maple syrup (1/3 of a cup maple syrup and 1 tbsp of brown sugar) just because maple syrup makes my life more amazing : ) It was just as equally delicious.
Both times I put three to four garlic cloves, minced, instead of the garlic powder (fresher).
I also added about a tablespoon of lemon juice to the marinade. 
I grilled the salmon in a bit of the marinade.

Important note: I would not marinate for more than half an hour. Two hours would completely take the taste of fish away, which I guess is fine for someone who doesn't like fish to begin with, but I love it. Just a matter of preference I guess.

text:
I made this marinade tonight at the last minute and only let it marinate for about 20-30 minutes but it was still delicious.  A little on the sweet side, but I like it that way. Instead of placing the salmon directly on the grill, I put them on aluminum foil over the fire (sprayed with non-stick spray). The skin still gets crispy and brown without any flare-ups.  I turned them over after about 5-6 minutes and moved them to indirect heat, closed the lid of the grill and let them sit another 4 minutes or so. They were cooked perfectly.

text:
Best salmon we've had.  Great recipe.  I had 2-3/4 lbs. of fish, which I cut into 5 fillets and marinated for a couple of hours.  Used lots of fresh cracked pepper in the marinade.  We grilled them in aluminum foil packets (with some air space above the fillets).  We kept them on the grill longer than the specified time, because the fillets were very thick.  Don't need to turn them over if you're using the foil packets method.  Absolutely delicious salmon!!

text:
This was ridiculously good. I mean GREAT! I have always just seasoned my Salmon with Kosher salt and fresh cracked pepper and have been satisfied. I always buy my fish fresh so I've never complained about the wonderful flavor that already exists in Salmon. However, I did want to try something new and just plain maple syrup squeezed on something so beautiful just doesn't seem to do it justice. So I decided to try this and I am so happy I did. My whole family LOVED this! I even used the exact same recipe and let it reduce on simmer in a pot and drizzled it on top. Thank you tinamenina for this awesome twist.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/344979.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used to be intimidated by the grill, but with recipes like this my confidence is swiftly growing. Plus, any recipe that calls for everything I already keep on hand (excluding fish ;) earns instant points at my house. I picked out skinless salmon portions rather than full-size fillets, which were perfect for me and my husband. The only thing I did at all differently from the recipe was cut down the brown sugar by about half. I also had a tube of lemon grass puree, so I added a little over a tablespoon of that. I could not be happier with the way these flavors work together. The fish developed a light, delicate crisp crust that kept those flavors laced through the moist, flaky flesh. This will definitely be my go-to recipe for salmon on the grill.

text:
Kinda tweaked this a tad. I did'nt use lemon pepper, just lemon juice, because I wanted cut the water down so that it would stay thick- and not run off while cooking. And used Olive oil instead of vegetable oil. Threw in a little dill to punch it up-- color and texture turned out amazing! grilled on a cedar plank for 20 mins. Served with white rice seasoned with lemon and parsley. SO YUMMY!! :)

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-07-11T19:32:51.453
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
7324638
Display Name:
CookinFool
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I skipped the lemon pepper, and garlic powder all together, as I thought that lemon might steal away from the sweetness(though not overly) and richness of the salmon. In place of the garlic powder, I minced up a large clove of garlic and added it to the zip-loc bag along with the rest of the marinade and the fish. I let it soak for about 8-10 hours before throwing it onto the oiled and preheated grill. I put it flesh side down first, and then flipped it over as recommended. Just before it was finished cooking, I flipped it back over to put some perpendicular(fancy looking) grill marks on it, and I peeled off the unappetizing skin.

The sauce that I improvised to put on the salmon was three parts Sweet Baby Ray's Barbecue Sauce/ two parts honey/two parts soy sauce. It was phenomenal, everyone(except my uncle) put it on their fish, in great quantity. I suggest using low sodium soy sauce, as the dish does have a lot of soy sauce in it and it may taste quite salty if you don't.

I served the fish with a rice pilaf, and steamed asparagus, and also with a nice riesling from the Columbia Valley in California. The dinner was a smashing success.

Try the sauce.
Review:
Rating:
4

Fantastic salmon recipe!  I seasoned the fillets, then let them sit in the plastic bag for 1 night without the marinade.  The following day, I added the marinade, and grilled them up that afternoon.  (I used my Foodsaver to "quick-marinade" the meat...works wonderful, and does the overnight job in about 20-25 minutes!)  Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

None
text:
I did not marinate first - time thing. Grilled on a cedar plank (10 minutes per inch is the "rule") and basted during grilling instead. Also, I used less sugar (@ 3 T.ish? I don't measure)  and a bit of natural honey. I will use all honey next time if I have some (about 3 T.) and eliminate the sugar altogether. Just a bit sweet the way I did it. Non salmon people may like this as the sweetness and grilling takes away some of the fishy taste.

text:
This recipe is so easy and delicious, it's become one of our favourite meals.  I usually skip the salt and the oil altogether and add a bit more water.  I find the soy sauce is plenty salty and I add a small drop of oil before grilling to prevent the salmon from sticking.

I like to keep all the ingredients on hand for unexpected guests because it's so easy and everyone loves it!  Nearly everyone I've made it for has asked for the recipe.

text:
Simple and Delicious. I was short on time so I sprinkled lemon juice (from 1/2 lemon) and the garlic powder over 4 thinner salmon fillets. Then I mixed the Soy, water, and Brown Sugar (my salmon was fatty so I skipped the oil). Marinated it for about 1/2 hour, placed on a baking dish (marinade and all) and baked at 475º for 12 minutes ('til it was flaky). This worked for me and it was tasty!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I never liked salmon until I tried this recipe.  Now we eat it often.  The flavors are a perfect blend and gives the salmon a slightly sweet taste. I find that the rich taste of sock-eye salmon is well suited to this marinade.  Also, salmon with the skin on it will have more flavor than skinned salmon.  Watch carefully as you grill.  Thinner fillets (like the tail end of the fillet) may not take a full 6 minutes per side.  You don't want the salmon to be dry from over-cooking.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe. My wife loved it, and she is not a huge seafood fan. I followed the recipe exactly except I used 1 clove of crushed garlic instead of garlic powder, and I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. After marinating I covered in tin foil, and baked in the oven at 375 degrees for 25 min. I served it with Uncle Bens boxed wild rice, a green salad, and a bottle of Pinot Grigio wine. Nice romantic meal for about $30.00 dollars with enough left overs for a great lunch the next day. You could easily build off this recipe and make it your own by adding stuff to the marinade such as thai chile and garlic paste, or tequila and lime juice etc......This salmon recipe is definately worth a try. The best part is, it's also a relatively healthy dish that you feel great after eating, and not fat and sluggish.

text:
I had a 2-1/2 lb Norwegian farmed fillet which I cut in half and placed on the oiled gas grill. I tented the fish with foil after about 10 mins b/c the bottom (skin side) was cooking faster than the top. The coals ended up catching fire and singing the skin, so I placed the salmon under the broiler for a couple minutes to finish it. It came out very moist with a hint of the marinade (next time I will marinate it for 3 or 4 hours instead of 2.) This is the best salmon I have ever cooked or eaten.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family *loves* this dish.  The first time I made it, I'd intended to grill the fish, but mother nature intervened (it rained) so I put the fillets in foil packets with a bit of the marinade spooned over each one and baked it at 375 for about 15 min.  It came out so well that they won't let me fire up the grill even when the sun is shining!   I've made it several times since and now simplify it by putting the lemon pepper, garlic powder and *no* salt (my husband has a heart condition) in the marinade which I make in a plastic bag.  Swish it around, add the fish and refrigerate until you're ready to bake.  Love it.

text:
Wow and thanks. It was delicious. Make sure to lightly oil grill/grill pan. Move it a bit on the grill after a minute or two to prevent it from sticking to the grill since the sugar will carmalize. Used kroger brand frozen salmon fillets thawed. Putting skin side down first, cooked for five minutes each side, then let sit in serving dish for 5 mins skin side up to rest.  I substituted extra virgin olive oil for vegetable oil, added a dash of ground red pepper. I used my cast iron grill pan. Served with rice and green onion kimchee and the kids liked it as well. Son said it would be great for chicken also. Thanks for a quick easy recipe.

text:
Easy & excellent!  My 4 yr. old loves it too.  I tend to like sauce so I take make the marinade enough for 6 servings (instead of 4) if I have a pound of salmon.  After I put the salmon in the oven, I take the leftover marinade and put it into a frying pan and let it simmer for the length of time the salmon is in the oven.  It slowly thickens & makes a super yummy sauce to top on the fish.

We normally arent real keen on Salmon but this was very good, I used Real Garlic in the marinade rather than the garlic powder (I usually only use garlic powder in dire situations because the real thing is just so much better.) and lemon juice and pepper instead of lemon pepper since I didn't have that on hand.    I baked this in the oven since it was like 5 below outside that day. (brrr, Minnesota!)  I took the advice of another user and wrapped my salmon in foil packets first then I baked it at 450 for 10 minutes and then opened them up and put them under the broiler for about 5 minutes.  I think I may be cooking salmon more often now that I know the right way to make it and I'm especially looking forward to trying this on the grill when the weather is a little more cooperative.  My whole family enjoyed this- even my 2 toddlers who are my biggest critics.  ;)

As the other reviewers suggested I cooked it in a foil packet as per the fish guy at the supermarket I cooked my piece for 25 minutes at 350. Oh and pour more of the marinade in the packet to pour on the fish when it is on the plate.

text:
This is totally amazing! I HATED salmon...this recipe was my one last shot at trying something to like salmon. It worked...we now have salmon Sundays in our house. I pierce the filet with a fork all over and put the salmon in the marinade, usually for a few hours. Hubby grills it while I make a side dish of jasmine rice w/peas and carrots and a green salad w/ginger dressing. My 2 changes: omit lemon pepper and garlic powder. Instead add fresh lemon juice to taste and fresh garlic. FYI, the leftovers are delish the next morning on a bagel w/cream cheese. YUM!!!

country:
None
text:
I added a touch of Sesame oil to the olive oil for a more Asian flavor and rice wine vinegar along with the lemon juice and zest, fresh ginger and crushed garlic.  I used Tamari instead of regular soy sauce, less sodium, more flavor.  I brought the remaining to a boil, reduced the marinade and used it as a glaze over the finished fillet.  Very good but after 7 minutes it was done through; seared, with a nice bark on one side and done through.  Next time I'll watch it more carefully.  This is almost the same marinade I regularly use for flank steak, minus the brown sugar.  I loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Needs to marinate longer. I have cooked salmon before with a similar recipe and it comes out much better if you marinate for at least 4-6 hours, however, I usually try and marinate it over night. Also, be careful about cooking the salmon with much of the juices of the marinade because the brown sugar can cause it to burn. I've given it five stars because it is a great base recipe, but I highly recommend adding about a 1/4 cup of bourbon and some cut up green onions. Superb!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We tried this recipe due to the overwhelming good reviews on this site. Unsurprisingly, we were not disappointed. 

The one thing I liked best about this recipe is that it uses simple ingredients found in any household, yet it tastes anything but ordinary.

We didn't have a grill, so we used a cast iron grill slab that fit right over our cast iron stove top. This cooking method turned out great. The only vice was a little bit of the brown sugar sticking to the grill plate. However, this was mostly due to me having the heat on too high initially, and the fact that this recipe really calls for a grill.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone, due to the great flavor and simple ingredients. I'll make this again.

**UPDATE--Made again. Didnt have any brown sugar, only Splenda, but I made this again anyway. Still just as good!!**-- I am giving this recipe 5 stars because it is super easy to make and with ingredients you already have in the house. I dont like my fish, or any meat for that matter, sweet but this was great.  It wasnt too sweet.  It took me minutes to put together and it was fantastic!  I didnt grill it, i made it on the stove and reduced the marinade after and poured it over the salmon when it was done.  It was yummy!  The only thing id change is use way way less oil, its really not needed.  Thanks for an easy and tasty recipe :)

I live in an apartment and can't grill so I baked it in the oven at 450 for 20 min. Other than that it was fantastic and I will make this again and again.

userID:
2236689
Display Name:
Maui Grill'n
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this on salmon and it was incredible.  I marinated for about 5 hours.

I also used this marinade for a pork loin. 

I seasoned the pork the same way it calls to do the salmon.  Then I marinated the pork in a plastic bag for 24 hours.  After taking the pork out of the bag I boiled the marinade. I then grilled the pork loins on medium heat for 30 minutes. (I have a gas grill.)  I basted every five minutes.  I turned the pork loins half way through.  The last few minutes I turned the grill up to high to char the outside.  I messed up and let the temp get to 160 on an instant thermometer, although it was moist I will pull it from the grill at about 22 minutes or 150 degrees next time as I like my pork a little less done than the standard 160. 

The pork turned out as good as the salmon!  Moist and delicious.  This goes PERFECT with pork loin!

5

text:
I marinaded these for a couple of hours & boy, were they packed w/ flavor! I don't care for salmon much because of the fishy taste & the marinade masked it very well...even I loved them. I was out of lemon pepper so I squeezed a bit of lemon juice on the filets & added some ground pepper. I did not add any salt because soy sauce is usually so salty. I cooked these inside on a grill pan & served them atop brown rice (cooked in chicken broth w/ sliced green onions), w/ steamed broccoli & cukes & onions marinaded in italian dressing (w/ a couple of squeezes of lemon juice)on the side. Will have this healthy dish many times!

We've made salmon a gazillion different ways and this was by far the best tasting for the least amount of hassle.  It works well to grill it skin side down against the shiny side of the foil. So good!!! yum!!! 
I recommend that if the lemon pepper has salt, you should omit extra salt. also use light soy sauce (its less salty) and olive oil instead of vegetable oil, it made the fillets very moist and tender. 
To grill, cook each side for 7 minutes if the coals are hot. i loved this recipe. great family meal, and even picky children enjoy it. best salmon I’ve had yet. it goes excellent with organic Trader Joes jasmine rice.

Delicious.  I ended up marinating the salmon overnight, then placed salmon along with all the marinade onto foil, to which I added some frozen broccoli and carrots and sealed it all up into a packet.  I then baked it at 400 degrees for about 25 minutes; the salmon was not quite done, so I opened the packet and let it bake another 15 minutes or so.  Came out great served over rice.  Nice flavor that doesn't overpower the salmon.

text:
I've never reviewed here before but had to for this recipe. I'm not a big fish lover - unless it's fish sticks or deep fried cod. But this recipe was fantastic! Even my 3, 6, and 7 year old kids loved it - and they're not big on fish either.

I didn't marinate it 2 hours. I used 2 of the individually wrapped salmon packets from Costco, put the fish in my frying pan, and salted and peppered it. Then I mixed the other ingredients together and drizzled on top. Also blended a little onion and garlic in my food processor and added to the mix - substituted Mrs. Dash for the lemon pepper and omitted the oil also.

I cooked it on med. high for about 15 minutes, then flaked the fish apart, and mixed the flakes with the sauce, I simmered for another 5 min. and served over brown rice with asaparagus.

Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
Yet another recipe from this site tht I crave!  Made this exactly as written (well OK, I used lemon juice and ground pepper separately) on the Foreman grill.  YUMMY!  I diod as others had suggested and saved the leftover marinade for extra cooking and thickening and drizzled the "sauce" over fresh spinich to wilt it and served salmon on top.  TO DIE FOR!  Then I decided to experiment by tweaking the recipe slightly.  I took out the pepper, left in everything else and added minced fresh ginger. I then sliced up some bok choy and sauteed it a bit to just get it slightly softened.  Again I took the "sauce" and drizzled it over and the salmon on top.  YUM YUM YUM!!!  Both ways are a big hit in this family - even the cat comes around to get some.  LOL THANKS, TINA.

text:
07/20/03 - 4 stars - In spite of marinating for 6 hours, DH (who dislikes salmon very, very much!) could only tolerate it accompanied by much wine!  I (who loves salmon every which way), on the other hand, thought the marinade made the salmon taste very mild.  I will try this again, probably marinating it for 24 hours...and serving it with 2 bottles of wine!

08/01/03 - 5 stars! - Yes, I made this again but substituted white wine for the water and marinated it over 24 hours.  It was so delicious!  I didn't think it tasted like salmon and my DH thought it was much better, although he said it still smelled like salmon!  I cooked his salmon very rare and he liked it more that way.  This is a keeper and will be made many times--so easy for company, too!

text:
Great taste.  This was the first time I ever tried to grill any kind of fish on my BBQ...and it stuck to the grate.  I turned it over and took it off the grill to finish for 1 minute in the microwave to avoid losing the other half of my fish.  I only wish that I would have saved the marinade to cook down so that I could have poured it over my fish when it was done (since a lot of the "flavor" part stuck to the grill).  I'll try it again...maybe with one of things to hold the fish on the grill without it actually touching the grate.  Thanks for sharing.

First time grilling a salmon filet right on the grate and it turned out perfect!  FYI, to make sure the grate was well oiled: heat the grill first; thoroughly oil a paper towel with some vegetable oil; use tongs to hold the paper towel and apply oil to heated grate.  This worked VERY well!

Put ingredients into ninja - including lots of lemon pepper poured out of grinder. I put a good 1 1/2 t garlic powder and add ginger from the tube. Marinate all day and drain marinade to a pan and boil with green onion for a minute or two and add fillets, cook, flip and cook and top with more green onion. Recipe is versatile and can grill, bake, broil or sauté. All delicious!!

text:
This is another great salmon recipe on this site. My family loves it. I have made few times following the recipe exactly, including cooking the fish on the grill. But if weather not permitting, I have made by marinating the fish in a casserole dish and baking it, in the same pan, at 400 ° F, for 15 to 20 minutes, depending on how thick the piece of Salmon is. Both ways, the salmon comes out delicious but you can't beat the smoky flavor the grill adds to it !

text:
This is a terrific basic recipe.  I've made it my "go to" recipe for summertime salmon, sometimes I add some dried herbs to the marinade like basil or some dried ginger if I have fresh ginger I just chop a piece of it and add it to the marinade baggie.  If I use ginger I use OJ instead of water.
I always grill it on a hinged griller that sandwiches the salmon before placing it on my BBQ, liberally sprayed with Pam. I leave the skin on too, but that's a matter of preference, we like it because it keeps the fish moist.
I only marinade the fish for an hour, because I like to taste the fish and not just the marinade.

Amazing recipe.  Completely gets rid of the oiliness of the fish that my husband always complains about with salmon. text:
Well...I'm 'stupidfied' about how good this is. I followed the recipe besides adding a little honey w/ the brown sugar. I let it thaw and marinate for 3-4 hours. My new Cusinart Griddle/Grill set at 350 degrees on both grill plates rendered an exceptional tasting fillet. Moist, not too salty (did use low sodium soy sauce), not to sweet...just wonderful. Can 28,000 reviewers be wrong (give or take a few thousand)? One time I added some Tabasco sauce and leek rings (needed to use). Whereas this is too salty to turn into a sauce by boiling, I might use this as my default marinade. Needle nose pliers worked well to pick pin bones. I like salmon skin, especially if it gets crispy.

text:
I have to get on the "I love this recipe" bandwagon!  It really was good...so simple and so flavorful.  I ended up grilling on the BBQ over gas flame...oil made flames shoot up like fireworks, and charred the skin.  But it was still very tasty.  My boys are more likely to eat anything when it's grilled over an open flame.  I will use this marinade with other meats as well.  By far, my favorite.  (substitutions: used olive oil instead of veggie oil/decreased soy sauce to 1/4 cup as suggested by other reviewer AND mixed it with special soy sauce for soups only and Memmi-soy sauce used for Udon noodle soup base/didn't have lemon pepper powder so used Myer lemon juice and ground pepper/used real garlic instead of powder). 
Thanks for posting this tinamenina.

text:
Very tasty.  Only thing we did  different was grill it on a well-soaked cedar plank.  Will make again.   Made this a second time and this time substituted water for white wine.  We baked it in the oven at 400 degree 15-20 min.  Love it and it is so easy.  Making it one of my "GO TO" salmon recipes.  Made it this time in my air fryer--360 degrees for 10 minutes.  Obviously this salmon is good any way you cook it.

This was great!!! I didn't have lemon pepper on hand so I used some lemon juice and pepper. Besides that I kept the recipe the same. I took the advice of others and placed the salmon flesh side down on the grill first and it did not stick at all. I also just mixed all the ingredients in the zip lock bag, makes no sense to dirty a bowl if you are just going to pour everything into the bag anyways. This is my favorite recipe for salmon that I have found.

text:
I did not have lemon pepper, so I just used a tablesppon of lemon juice on the salmon. As suggested by another reviewer, I started with the salmon side down. I am not sure that it mattered because I was using a George Foreman Grill. With the lid down, it cooked on both sides. Even so, I still cooked it for 8 minutes and then flipped the salmon for 5 more minutes. (I was cooking a 2 lb. piece of salmon.) I was perfect! It was flaky, but still juicy. Next time I will marinate overnight and not just 2 hours. I would like to see if I can get more of the soy sauce flavor. This is a great salmon recipe!!

text:
I used frozen salmon fillets and marinated for less than 30 minutes because I decided I wanted salmon at the last minute. My usual go to recipe for salmon (which calls for ginger and other ingredients I don't usually keep on hand) was not an option. This recipe was simple, used ingredients found in most every kitchen, and was delish. I added red pepper flakes for taste and instead of grilling I baked them individually wrapped in foil at 400 for 20 minutes. If you want more of a glaze atop the fish, just unwrap them after cooking time, brush with the juices and broil for a minute or so.

Display Name:
califmtbguy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried a LOT of salmon marinades. My dad always swore by brown sugar but he uses Dijon mustard in his "go-to" recipe which I always found a bit strong. I tried this marinade just the way it is ingredient-wise. The thing I did do that may be a bit different was that I took a grilling basket and grilled it flesh side down like the reviewer KATHY had mentioned. Using the grilling basket you avoid a lot of the meat tending to stick to the grill.  I then finished it off skin side down. That really left a nice brown sugar glaze on the top but allowed me to finish it off slowly and still peel the meat right from the skin. Worked great. Go easy on the "to-taste" seasonings if you like the salmon flavor to burst through. The lemon-pepper adds a nice flavor. definitely 5 star.

None
text:
This is so close to my favorite fix for salmon.  I use equal parts low sodium soy sauce, brown sugar and lemon juice and a generous amount of fresh grated ginger.  The lemon juice balances the brown sugar so it isn't so sweet.  I then baste while cooking for added flavor.  Love it!  Also for those who blame this recipe for being fishy, It is likely because your fish was on the verge of spoiling.  Salmon is healthy and it is not fishy when fresh. It may also help you if you remove the skin.

Seriously the best salmon I have ever tried! I followed the top comments advice on cutting back some of the soy sauce and it was delicious. It reminded me off the eel roll sushi, which is my favorite.  I definitely will be making this again. :-p I just realized I never wrote what I did different, I didnt have lemon pepper so i used just a little bit of lemon juice over the fish with some black pepper. I cut down the soy sauce to 1/4 cup instead. I also put the salmon in a glass dish to let it cook in its own juices. I didnt even let it marinade for a couple hours and it still turned out amazing!

text:
After spending $30 + on 2 pounds of Alaskan wild salmon we chose this recipe and were so happy we did.  We changed nothing and followed the advice of the Alaskan resident that said to  cook it meat side down for about 7 minutes and then turn and cook skin side down for about seven minutes. Ours was a thick cut and I used a meat thermometer to bring the internal temperature to 145 degrees.   I did use Pam for grilling spray and was glad I did.

text:
For those who say that it was bland: the fish needs good seasoning with salt and garlic, soya sauce doesn't do the job because it's in the mix. Also depends on the thickness, mine was bit more than 1". When the fish goes in the marinade, it kind of washes away the salt from the fish. Anyway, we liked this recipe, but needs some experience in seasoning to get it great.

I ate half of it 4 hours later and it was better, no fishy taste at all!

I boiled the marinade for a couple of minutes and it was great-just couple tablespoons-over basmati rice. Love anything with soya,sugar and garlic mix.

text:
Wow!  I have always blackened Salmon and it's always been a hit, but this adds so much!  I did the marinate exactly following the recipe.  Once ready to grill (which I used the griddle on my stove top) I seasoned with garlic salt, Magic Salmon Seasoning and Garlic Pepper on both sides.  Grilled well on first side till blackened, flipped and covered until done and blackened on 2nd side.  This marinate added such a wonderful sweet crispness to the blackening, I'll definitely use it again!

text:
UPDATE: I NEEDED AN EASY MEAL TO SERVE GUESTS (MY PARENTS). MY HUBS AND I HAD A BUSY DAY AND TIME IN THE KITCHEN WAS LIMITED. THIS FIT THE BILL PERFECTLY. FYI, AS OTHERS HAVE ADVISED, GRILL YOUR FISH SKIN SIDE UP FIRST. IT MAKES ALL THE DIFFERENCE! I wouldn't say this is the BEST salmon I've ever had (it's decent...), but it's quick to prepare (marinating aside) and made for a fuss-free, satisfying dinner. It took less than 15 minutes for my husband to grill our fish and for me to assemble our sides (steamed jasmine rice and Cooking_Muse's Japanese-style green beans). While there are other salmon recipes I've enjoyed much more flavor-wise, it's nice to have a quick option to turn to when life gets a little hectic! I can see this becoming a staple just for that. :) Thanks for sharing your recipe, tinamenia!

text:
My cooking skills are barely beyond boiling water, but this grilled salmon recipe worked out great for me. I did reduce the brown sugar by about 40% and used olive oil in place of vegetable oil. I grilled the marinated salmon skin side down first, using a "Denmark Cast Aluminum Grill and Griddle" on a ceramic cooktop. I covered it with a skillet lid and cooked it for 6 min per side. The 1/2 lb salmon fillet was bought at my local supermarket since I live in "fly over country". It was wonderfully tender and tasty skin included. Accompanied with a rice medley and washed down with a cold beer.

country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out quite nicely. I let it marinate for 3 hours and cooked it to perfection. It was perfectly cooked. However, for my taste, it was slightly too salty and sweet. It may be all right for most, but I would cut the amount of sugar and salt to maybe 2/3 of what is called for. I'm not much of a sweet-for-dinner person anyway and I have sensitive taste. I also added about three Tbs of lemon to break down the meat just a little and add some spunk. It was amazing because it helped the salmon melt in the mouth even more! Ah, and when I cooked it, I cooked it covered the entire time to keep moisture and cooked at medium low heat to avoid burning.

I give this salmon about 3.5 stars. The best recipe by far for fish!!!!

I use 1/3 C lemon juice and black pepper to taste along w/ sea salt and garlic powder. I also wrap it in a foil packet and bake for about 20 mns on 450 and then broil it for about 6 more mns. It is so good this is the only way I will cook fish and all my kids (7,5,3, and 1) and my husband LOVE IT!!!! It is so good w/ the balsamic asparagus and crock pot mashed potatoes recipes from this site.

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time making this we guesstimated on the measurements and didn't have time to marinate for the two hours but it was still delicious even with just the hint of the seasoning - also note: I used garlic salt instead of garlic powder+table salt. The second time I measured things out properly and although still very good, I found it to get a little overwhelming with the salt about half way through the filet. I like sweet with salmon so next time I will use a little less soy sauce than called for and a little more brown sugar.

Update: I kept the left over marinade (that I had set aside to brush on while grilling) and added about two pinches more brown sugar to what was probably 4-5 tablespoons left of marinade. I coated the left over salmon and slow re-heated it. It was perfect; not too sweet at all and cut down the salt taste just enough. Delicious!
