text:
No need to grill this at all.  I love the foil packet idea.  It is a great way to serve salmon to a large group.  I get a huge slab of salmon and Costco, and cut them into individual fillets, depending on number of guests.  Also, I usually don't marinade at all, I just divide up the marinade evenly and poor in the foil pocket and then each guest can use the left over sauce to poor over their brown rice.  So flavorful, so healthy, and kids really like it too.  Definitely favorite salmon recipe, just as good as restuarant prepared salmon, actually better!!!!

text:
Ok, so I made this for my fam tonight....instant winner! My 7 yr old loved it and my 4 yr old cleaned her plate! my husband who had already had dinner with the boys and "just wanted a bite" ate a full serving. And he doesn't "like fish" I did make a few changes...fresh lemon and cracked pepper as well and minced garlic and onion. Also only 1/8 c olive oil in place of veg oil. I grilled flesh down for 1 min, made a 1/4 turn and grilled another min I love markings. Flipped skin down, basted with marinade and grilled 7 mins. Added corn starch to remaining marinade and reduced for a sauce. Already planning on making this again!

text:
Amazing recipe! The salmon cooked amazingly with just 7 minutes on the fleshy side, and about 4-6 minutes on the skin side. It was so moist and flavourful. I marinated it for an hour instead of 2 because they say you shouldn't marinate fish for more than an hour (only the very richest for that long, and others for no more than 30 minutes) because the acid starts to break down the proteins, causing a mushy fish. 

Excellent recipe!

text:
I use this recipe very often but substitute honey for the brown sugar and water. Only using equal parts oil (either olive oil or sunflower seed oil) honey and soy sauce. I cook in an oven of 435f skin side up so as to protect the soft meat and then flip after about 10 minutes to brown the top basting after I flip. I serve with homemade fried rice and oven roasted sliced red bell peppers. A wonderful meal full of flavor!

text:
I used a little less brown sugar and substituted olive oil.   I also used fresh lemon rather than lemon pepper and no salt.   This turned out great!  This enhanced the salmon flavor without overwhelming it.  The last few times we grilled the salmon without marinating and although it's good, it's just a little bland.  I will definitely make this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First I have to say that I didn't follow this recipe exactly as stated.  I used garlic powder + fresh garlic, and lemon pepper + lemon juice.  I also only used about 1 T of vegetable oil since I was baking and not grilling so I figured I didn't need that much.  

I baked the salmon in individual foil pouches at 425 for 15 min like others recommended and the salmon came out nice and moist.  Unfortunately I was disappointed that there was very little taste other than saltiness (and on the thinner parts of the filet it was way too salty).  I didn't really taste lemon or garlic or anything else, even though in the original sauce I did.  

I saved the sauce as recommended and added more brown sugar plus a bit of honey as well as flour to thicken it up.  It was a delicious sweet and salty sauce but unfortunately I could not use it since the salmon itself was already too salty without additional sauce.

I read other reviews that said this sauce overpowered the taste of the salmon and I both agree and disagree.  The saltiness made some of the thinner parts of the salmon taste just awful and yes - it covered up the taste of the salmon!  However, in the middle and with thicker filets, the salmon was very obvious and the sauce (well, saltiness was subtle.

I will try this recipe and perhaps add a little honey to the original recipe and play around with the ingredients a little more since I like the idea of a salty sweet glaze for salmon and I like the ingredients list.

text:
Have made this recipe over and over again with little adjustments here and there for difference spices/herbs.  If you worry about burning the salmon on the BBQ I found that you can cook the salmon in a glass pyrex dish and cook it in the marinade at 350 for about 30 minutes.  This cooks the flavour into the fish and you can usse some of the leftover to top onto the salmon on the plate.

userID:
3906575
Display Name:
Bucho
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

4

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my most dependable go-to recipes.  My wife sometimes likes me to add crushed ginger to the marinade, and I sometimes squeeze some fresh lemon juice at the end, but the original recipe is still darn good.  To get optimal results you should grill over coals, lump charcoal being my preference.  Being able to grill year-round is one of the best things about living in South Florida.  Since fish fillets tend to stick on the grill (even a well oiled one)I like to grill on a sheet of oiled aluminum foil placed right on top of the hot grate, and the salmon always turns out perfect.

text:
wow this was a hit! i put it in foil and put it on the grill. when i placed it in foil, i put in about a spoonful of the sauce as well as squeezed fresh lemon over it to give it a kick. then i wrapped and put it on the grill for about 6 minutes or so without flipping. (if you flip it, the sauce might drip out of the foil) one time, i accidentally left it there  for a while and forgot but it didnt burn much, thank goodness! even with the light burn, it tasted good! haha! i also did this same recipe in the oven and it turned out great. so over the grill or in the oven, BOTH ARE GREAT! thanks for the recipe!

text:
I used lemon juice instead of lemon pepper and I also substituted fillets with salmon steaks.    I packed it in foil packets and baked in the oven.   It was scrumptious!  To reheat it for a later meal, I put it in a frying pan and dumped the marinade over it and reduced the marinade over low heat until it was slightly syrupy.  This made is taste like a teriyaki salmon with a slight tang.  Better than regular teriyaki! Very tender and flavorful both ways. Will make again.

text:
Never grilled salmon before.  I followed the recipe to a 'T', marinated it for about four hours, grilled it flesh side down first, and then finished skin side down.  THIS WAS WONDERFUL!!! EVERYONE loved it...I was really impressed. We grilled it so the skin was almost black, the darker, the crispier. I never thought I'd eat salmon skin...I enjoyed it very much. Marinating it for at least a couple of hours is a must, the marinade permeates the flesh wonderfully.  This was SOOOO easy, quick to grill, and fantastic tasting.  We will definitely do it again.

text:
Outstanding flavor! The only problem was that the fish completely fell apart on the grill.  :-( Next time I will try a grill basket or cage.  I used 1 T. lemon juice and freshly cracked black pepper (in place of lemon pepper seasoning) and 1/4 cup maple syrup (in place of the brown sugar).  I also scored the salmon with a knife before marinating and let it sit in the fridge for about 4 hours.  The scoring helps it pick up the flavor of the marinade in a short period of time.  YUM!

text:
Absolutely LOVE this marinade!  It is truly one of the best I have ever paired with salmon for grilling.  I substituted lemon pepper with fresh lemon juice ( 1 lemon) and ground pepper.  Plus I substituted soy sauce with lite soy.  Since the marinade is so good - do not discard the extra rather put it that aside & use as a dipping sauce or pour over the salmon once it has been removed from the grill.  I paired this with rice & mixed some of the extra sauce with the rice.  A must have recipe.

text:
Wow! My husband and I went to an upscale Japanese restaurant in Milwaukee and I swear I had this same recipe salmon--it's amazing! I followed the ingredients exactly, but changed the cooking method a bit. Since we have never properly seasoned our grill, I cooked this in a foil packet with a lot of the marinade and it was SOOO flavorful and tender. I never flipped it and it took about 15-20 minutes over med-high heat and it didn't dry out at all (I had about 1 1/2 lbs I think).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salmon had great flavor but I can't rate it 5 stars because I'm comparing it to the Baked Salmon recipe on this site that is really out of this world. I would defintely give it a 4.5 though... I didn't time to marinate it so I placed 2 fillets in foil, combined the salt, pepper, and garlic powder and rubbed it on to the fillets. Then, I poured the marinade over the fish, sealed the foil and baked at 425 for about 20 min. The cook time was really too long (my fault - too much happening at once) but the flavor came out nice - not too over powering. Served over brown rice. I will make this again for sure, but next time will cook 15-17 min and see how that works. I also reduced some reserved marinade and pour it over the salmon and rice - that was too strong - too sweet and too salty. I wouldn't do that again.

text:
This is one is great. Wonderful marinade for salmon! I also substituted olive oil for vegetable oil and it worked beautifully.  I grilled face down for 3 minutes then rotated 45 degrees to get those nice grill lines for an additional 3 minutes. When I flipped it I flipped it onto foil and pored the remaining marinade over top of  it and grilled for 7 more minutes.  When I removed from the grill the skin stuck to the foil. The salmon stakes looked and taste like something you would get at a five star restaurant. I served with wild brown rice and steamed broccoli. Actually felt healthy after we ate it. Thanks for the recipe.

userID:
2248199
Display Name:
Tasty
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/104734.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found that this recipe really made the salmon tasty and a bit crispy.  I baked the fish in the marinade for 15 minutes covered at 350 in a preheated oven, and then put it in the broiler for five minutes at broil, uncovered w/no marinade.  A baking sheet will do, but be sure to spray the pan with Pam (the type of your choice).  This fish came out nice and flaky.  

Keep in mind that I used "light" brown sugar.  It was the only sugar in my house.  I suppose if you use regular brown sugar or honey (something I'm contemplating for a shorter trip in the broiler) the outcome might be somewhat different and a bit crispier.

Another nice thing about this recipe is that it is versatile, and allows each user to customize their own experience, by refraining from including measurements for garlic, lemon pepper, and other spices.

It was a great success.  

My only suggestion is double the recipe!

text:
I used lemon juice and pepper (as suggested by another reviewer). I also used minced garlic instead of garlic powder per another reviewer. I did not add salt, as others suggested. I reduced the soy sauce in half and cut out the salt (as others suggested). I doubled this recipe as my salmon was a 2.5 lb fillet I marinated it over night and cooked it for dinner in a convection oven, sealed in aluminum foil at 400 for 25 minutes because of the thickness of my fillet. This recipe is amazingly versatile. The whole idea of contrasting the sweet and the salt for this recipe is just great and makes the fish so succulent. My husband loved it !! My son, who shys away from fish is now beginning to try it due to recipes like this !! Thanks for the submission.

text:
I've made this 4 times now and it was really good each time.  I first tried it as written.  This was good.  I would probably have given it 4 stars.  Then I took the tip from another reviewer and used half the oil and mandarin oranges.  I reduced the remaining marinade with some corn starch and water and used it as a sauce. Again this was good, and again I would give it 4 stars.  On the third and fourth times I took a different reviewer's tip and cut the oil to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce.  I grilled it on a cedar plank on the grill.  This was SPECTACULAR!!!  My husband hates fish and hates it when I make fish.  He told me three times that he liked it and couldn't believe he liked it.  I'm giving it 5 stars because it is such a versatile recipe and because it impressed my picky fish-hating husband.  I do recommend getting a high quality salmon and I really liked using spicy BBQ sauce.  I used Famous Dave’s Devil Spit on the fourth version and I think that was my favorite.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-07-19T09:25:22.203

I did marinate overnight and it still didn't have a lot of punch.  Hubby thought it was great.

Incredible!  Living in the Pacific NW we tend to eat a lot of seafood...I love it when I find a new recipe that tastes great and is easy. text:
Absolutely the BEST Salmon recipe ever!  I have loads of Kokanee Salmon that my husband keeps on catching, and I was looking for a delicious recipe that we wouldn't tire of - this is it!  Even great cold the next day.  Kokanee are small and sweet, so I turned my grill pan to Medium High and grilled the filets, flesh side down first, for 3 minutes per side.  They turned out perfect, and even a guest who doesn't eat fish liked this Salmon.  Truly an awesome recipe that I have had to share several times!  Thanks so much!

text:
Great taste. Wonderful. Sear the non scale side first, then turn. It locks in the taste. Cook longer on scale side down and tent with a piece of foil to complete cooking time. The foil tent insures it is done and helps it stay moist. When I removed it from large grill pan on top of my stove the scale side stayed on the grill pan the the fish was removed easily. Looked like something from an upscale resturant.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/347504.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband asked "what did you do different to the salmon?" when we ate this for dinner, LOL, and he really liked it. I cut the soy sauce to about 1/4 cup, used 2 Tbsp of lemon juice instead of lemon pepper and added brown sugar to taste, between 1/3 and 1/2 cup. I let it marinate overnight, baked it for about 15 minutes and then broiled it for a few more minutes. Be careful broiling though, because the sugar will burn quickly. The salmon had an almost teriyaki taste, but much better. I will definitely be making this one again.

text:
One word: Yum! We are not fish fans around here but we are trying to add it to our diets. This is a phenomenal recipe! I only had time to marinate it for an hour and it was still delicious. The only changes I made was to use lemon juice instead of lemon pepper(didn't have any) and I baked it at 450 for 15 minutes in foil pouches at the suggestion of another reviewer. Also made a sauce out of the extra marinade I made, also at the suggestion of another reviewer. It was a great decision. I served the salmon over arugula with garlic-steamed asparagus and Parmesan risotto. It is definitely a meal worthy of serving to guests. Thanks!

Display Name:
Brian

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic simple recipe!! Just had it tonight for my birthday...A SMASH!! I'm the BBQer in the family. I used 1.5 lbs and there was plenty of juice to cover it. Instead of lemon pepper I used fresh cracked pepper and a fresh lemon. I cracked the pepper over the salmon after i put the juice of 1 lemon over it and let it sit for about 20 minutes. I put a medium sized garlic clove, chopped finely, instead of garlic powder and the zest of 2 lemons  in the soy sause mix along with the garlic for about 20 minutes to meld everything together. I let it marinate for only about an hour but it still turned out great! The next time I do this one (and I will), I will use a little less brown sugar. It was fairly sweet. The burst of lemon from the zest was a fantastic little surprise as well. A+ Cook on a medium low setting... P.S. a turnable vegetable basket makes the turning super simple..no fish through the grill and super easy clean up.

Absolutely delicious, flavorful yet not over powering. I did let it marinate over night.  (used wild salmon filet with the skin) cooked in a basket on the grill. I served the salmon with summer squash that were sauteed with butter,onions,salt, pepper and when finished added bacon bits and parm cheese.  Also had some creamy horseradish on the side to dip in.  Pickled beets, cottage cheese, salad and a glass of wine!
I am going to make the marinate and put the fish in a small pan, freeze with marinate and then vacuum seal it.  Ready for the grill.

text:
The salmon was very tender but I did not think that the marinade had much flavor after it was cooked, which is why I gave this recipe 3 stars instead of 4.
Update:  Baked at 450 for 15 minutes in foil packets and it was more flavorful.  Doubled the marinade and boiled to use as a sauce.  Doubling not necessary - one batch is enough sauce.  Also, 10-12 min should be enough cooking time.

country:
None
text:
I don't like fish or any other seafood besides fishsticks, but I'm trying to eat healthier and salmon is one of the 14 superfoods I'm trying to add to my diet. The reason I don't like salmon is because it has a "fishy" taste to it, but once I was served smoked salmon and the fishy taste was absent. So I added 2 tsp. of liquid smoke to the recipe and then cooked the salmon on my George Foreman grill for 6 minutes and it came out wonderful. The liquid smoke eliminated the fishy taste and I loved it. So if anyone out there doesn't like seafood because of the fishy taste, then just add some liquid smoke and you'll love it. I even went back for seconds and will be making it again tonight for my boyfriend who says I never cook. Yum.

None
text:
This salmon recipe is by far the best i've tried and tasted! i substituted the brown sugar for normal white sugar and it still came out fabulous, despite marinating for about 5 hours! i also substituted garlic powder for 2 large cloves of garlic, omitting the vegetable oil completely, and added half a tablespoon of cooking Sherry, and 1 lemon (i sliced whatever i could and added the juice of the corners). the salmon was grilled with butter and put in foil packets, heated over the BBQ. FABULOUS! (we loved the marinade so much, we boiled it and served over the salmon) thanks loads for this recipe!!!

I have been making this for years and the only change I make is to omit the lemon pepper(personal preference), add1 tablespoon of liquid smoke  and everything else as written.   Marinated for 3 hours and baked in 450 degree  oven for 12 minutes broil for 5 minutes and make a glaze from the marinade using cornstarch. It's the only way my husband likes salmon.  Great smokey sweet flavor!

11
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
83
favoritesCount:
1642
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5239802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For simple & savory- this is a great option! I opted to try this outside of my favorite salmon recipe, because I wanted something “less” to really let the flavor of Alaskan salmon stand out. This didn’t disappoint! But, it also left the palate wanting a little more, so I would make a slight modification next time. I will be making this again! 

My suggestion would be to skip adding the water to the marinade, or add significantly less than called for. It was too runny, so I don’t think it did as well as a thicker marinade would have, in really coating & sticking. 

The flavor really is outstanding! I prefer ginger & lemon with many fish recipes, so I added a bit of fresh ginger flakes & a few squirts of lemon to the filets while seasoning, prior to marinade. I think it enhanced the flavor quite a bit, as the citrus penetrated what the marinade didn’t. 

The bake time always seems so short with fish! But, trust this one. 12 minutes was dang near perfect. Another 5 on broil was almost too much. I suggest checking at the 3 minute mark & turning the oven off to let it sit & cool as the broiler coils cool- evens it out very well. And I will be trying this one again! Really an easy & classic recipe for a sweet & savory salmon.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Wow!! This was really good! I got lazy and didn’t feel like firing up the BBQ so I just baked uncovered at 400 in the same Pyrex dish I marinated in. 25 minutes later, I had salmon that was so tasty and moist. Even my picky 5 yr old liked it.
I made 2 ingredient changes: I didn’t have lemon pepper so I used black pepper and juice from 1 lemon. And I substituted the vegetable oil with melted butter. 
I will make this again on the grill to see which one I like better. Either way, this recipe is a keeper !

text:
This is the first time I've ever used this recipe. Since I didn't have lemon pepper, I used a TBS of lemon zest and a pinch of white pepper. I love garlic so I minced a TBS and used just a pinch of garlic powder. I like sea salt and olive oil, so I used these ingredients and dark brown sugar, and low sodium soy sauce as well. My husband bbq'd it on a cedar plank and we loved it! We'll be using this marinade recipe for many years to come.

region:

country:
None
text:
I cooked the salmon on the stove using a grill pan, which works just as good as grilling it on an outdoor grill. Using medium heat, I placed the salmon in the pan with all of the marinade and brought it to a boil letting it soak up the marinade for 1-2 minutes. Then I poured the marinade out and continued to grill the salmon 6-8 minutes per side. The salmon comes out very moist and tasty!

country:

text:
So, as usual, I didn't plan ahead much so I didn't have two hours to marinate.  So... I took my 15 minutes as I prepared everything else (heating grill and making salad) and then I put the salmon in a little aluminum foil packet and threw that on the grill with quite a bit of the marinade.  Well, it turned much more like a poached salmon but the flavors were delicious.  Oh and I don't measure too much either so I know that I didn't use the full amount of brown sugar- maybe a couple of tablespoons until I thought it tasted good and then I put it over the fish.  Will definitely use this again.

text:
I used real maple syrup in place of brown sugar. (I was out of brown sugar.) So glad I made that decision. Brown sugar would make it too sweet. I also added olive oil, lemon juice and balsamic vinegar to the marinade.  No water. Be careful not to overcook it. Better to have it a bit underdone. You can heat it up in the micro for one minute. Perfecto!

text:
No time to Marinate. I made the sauce in a saucepan, added about 1/2 tsp ginger. Boiled it and then added some cornstarch and made a very thick glaze.  Baked my 1 lb. filet for 12 min, put on the glaze and broiled on high for about 1 min, till glaze stared to bubble. The taste was wonderful, my husband loved it. I was able to save enough sauce for another meal.

I've been making a very similar recipe for many years, with the exception of adding 1/3 cup teriyaki as well as replacing garlic powder with fresh minced garlic cloves  and juice of fresh lemon instead of lemon pepper .  Broiling when unable to grill out, it also turns out wonderful.   I have made salmon lovers out of many people that were seafood haters!  Better than most high end Salmon selections at restaurants, this recipe is delicious and it's  a regular in my rotation!  Great leftover too! (if you have any!!)

text:
I reduced the H2O to 1/4-cup, so my blend was 1/3 C soy sc, 1/3 C brown sugar, & 1/4-C each of water & EVOO.
I also used the juice of 1/4 lemon, rather than zest the waxed peel.

I pan-sautéed the filets, as it was raining heavily, & grilling fish while holding an umbrella is awkward, at best.  :—))

Great taste, nice & moist - not too sweet, a little tangy.
Yum!

Display Name:
L
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5841053.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best salmon I’ve ever had. It’s such a simple recipe, I couldn’t believe how wonderful it tastes. I didn’t use the lemon pepper or the garlic powder. I whisked the olive oil, water and brown sugar and low sodium soy sauce together, then used a microplane zester to grate 2 cloves of garlic, a generous knob of ginger, and the zest of a lime into the mixture. I put the filets in a 9”X13” pan, put the dish in a cold oven and set it at 450 degrees. It took about 15 minutes (my filets were on the thin side). I boiled the remaining marinade and poured it over the filets, letting them rest for 2-3 minutes before serving. Delícia!!! Thank you for this recipe. I’ll be making it quite a bit!

text:
Ok, I was looking for a new salmon marinade and this one was a hit. I used all the spices for taste and tweaked the amount of wet ingredients as I only used about 3 TBS of Olive oil, not Vegetable oil, 2 TBS of brown sugar, and approx 3-4 TBS of water and dissolved it and poured over the salmon. I chose to oven bake the salmon in foil pouches at 375 degrees for 22 minutes. It came out perfect moist and delicious! Thank you for this great recipe.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, I'm a terrible cook and this turned out awesome on the first try! My whole family loved it. I cooked it exactly as the instructions say (with my poor track record, I can't afford to improvise, lol). I cooked it on the grill (medium heat). First, flesh side down for 7 minutes, then skin side down for another 7 minutes (as the reviewer from Alaska suggested), and it came out gorgeous and cooked to perfection. I also heated the left-over marinade and added 1 tablespoon of corn starch, bringing it to a boil, to make a "gravy" (as suggested by another reviewer), which also turned out delicious. Some put the gravy on their salmon. Others put it on their rice. I put it on my salmon, rice, and broccoli, it was so good. : )

Made the marinade just as written and marinated salmon approximately 3 hours. The flavor was very light not overpowering. If you are looking for a more robust flavor this recipe may not be to your liking. We did grill the salmon on a gas grill at medium heat starting with skin side up for about 8 minutes then flipped over and grilled for another 8 minutes let it rest on a cover plate for another 5 minutes.

country:
None
text:
Instead of marinating the salmon, I mixed smaller amounts of the marinade ingredients and used it as a glaze throughout grilling it. I brushed it on, over the top of the dry seasonings, let it grill for 10 minutes and then brushed more on. We repeated this every 10 minutes throughout the cooking time. It saved time and kept the salmon moist during grilling. My husband said it was the best salmon he's ever had! Our kids even loved it.

For the first time in 5 years, I made something my husband literally would not even take more than one bite of. I made salmon the night before and everyone loved it as usual (good ol simple blackened Cajun and Boston bay rub). He got back out the leftovers tonight and left this recipe for me and the dogs. He held the leftovers under my nose and I was admittedly jealous that he got last night’s leftover salmon - first time in my life I’ve EVER been envious of leftover salmon. I ate this salmon and three of my four dogs absolutely loved it. Apparently the chihuahua and my husband were some of the few who thought this recipe was just terrible. I thought it was a 2. Edible but definitely not twice. Barring this being expensive home-made dog food, This recipe was a total fail.

country:
None
text:
I thought the marinade was good, but my partner thought it was too salty.  My only complaint is some of the reviews said the marinade burned off when grilling and it was really to cold to grill the evening I wanted to cook salmon, so I took the advice of some other reviews and baked it, but the oven was too hot at 425 degrees for 15 minutes, so the salmon was dry.  If you need to bake it, do so at 350 degrees for about 10 minutes depending on the thickness of the salmon.  I will try it again because it is different, but will skip adding salt since soy sauce has enough salt.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salmon is amazing! Substituted minced garlic that I pressed into the fish for garlic powder and also cooked only 4 minutes on each side instead of 6 the second time I made it cuz 6 makes it to dry.  Also cut down the oil a bit.  2 hours marinading is ok.... but if you can do 4-6 or even overnight it’s great.  Cilantro instead of parsley for sure.  Be generous with the amount of fresh lemon you squeeze on it at the end makes it so much tastier! Try with a side of balsamic brussel sprouts or asparagus and sliced avocado sprinkled with Himalayan sea salt and lemon.  YUM!

Display Name:
ilychocochip

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a huge salmon fan.  I regulary eat it so I am a pretty tough critic.  I was looking for a recipe to replicate the sweet salmon you can buy at  the grocery store without paying the high price. I must admit, this marinade is seriously delicious and really compliments the taste of salmon so well. Why 4 stars? After marinating overnight and baking the fish in the oven (I followed other users and baked, then broiled).   Once cooked, the flavor was bland but it is my fault.  I should have boiled the marinade in a seperate pan then topped the fish before broiling.  Next time though,  I will add a bit of bourbon, use regular sodium soy sauce (I used low sodium and the fish really needed the salt), marinate overnight using an oven bag, then cook the fish in the bag with the marinade before broiling. I think that's the missing step in this recipe. I will have to make it again & update my review later.

5

text:
It is a little sweet, but all in all very good. The only change I made was that I use a hot grill, about 400 - 450 degrees and grill it for about 3 to 4 minutes per side. As a person that lived in Alaska for 30 years I've grilled hundreds of salmon fillets and unless you have a fillet that is over 1" thick 12 to 18 minutes on the grill will leave you with dry salmon.

text:
Outstanding. Best ever.  I did marinate for 5 hrs. Preheated grill on high for 5 minutes then turned to medium for 5 minutes. I sprayed aluminum foil shiny side up and put on the  cookie sheet, added Salmon and carried to the grill.  Pick up aluminum on each end and put on grill and grill for 7 minutes each side. Perfectly grilled with grill marks. Use pot holder to lift foil and put back on cookie sheet. No messy grill to clean or pan..

text:
Looove this recipe it's easy to make and comes out perfect every time. I did take the hint from a previous poster and cooked it in the oven. After leaving the salmon in the soy sauce-brown sugar mixture overnight or at least about 6hours, I place it in individual foil pouches with the seasoning and some of the marinade. I cook it for about 15 minutes depending on the thickness of the salmon. It came out flaky and flavorful. One of my go to recipes for salmon.

text:
Good recipe. 
If I make it again, I would pat dry the salmon ...it was too wet. I used spray oil on my grill pan (worried the salmon would stick)and with the wet salmon, it was too much moisture. 
If you are watching your salt intake, you don't need it. The soy sauce is good flavor without. 
I also used frozen steaks and it was real good.

OMG, this was wonderful.  Turned out beautifully.  Can't wait to make again.  Have already shared the recipe.  Following others' suggestions, I used olive oil in place of vegetable oil and baked in foil pouch for 10 minutes, then broiled for 4.  Didn't have lemon pepper so mixed some pepper in lemon juice.  Also, as suggested, added corn starch to remaining marinade to thicken and poured lightly on salmon and rice pilaf.  To die for!!!  I will try just  a tad less brown sugar next time.  Thanks for this recipe.  It's a winner.

text:
Fantastic marinade!  I didn't add salt because the soy sauce has enough sodium in it, and it was very good.  The only thing I would do differently is to add less water - only because I used frozen salmon.   After cooking, the marinade was a little too watery, but the flavors were spot on.  Hubby is very picky about his salmon and he absolutely loved it!  He didn't even mind it being a little watery, but I did.  Will definitely make again (using less water next time).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made the marinade according to the recipe.  I usually get 2.5-3 pound fillets, and double or triple the amount of marinade.
Cooked over coals, on foil.
Skin side down, do not flip.  
When the meat can be flaked apart, it is done.  The skin will stick to the foil.  Less clean up afterwards.
Have made this several times, and is my go to for salmon.
Once again (every year) I made it for a golfing weekend during lent with the guys.  One told me that he does not like salmon, but that this was awesome.  Another described it as "like eating candy".
I cannot rate this high enough.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe dozens of times and recently had a guest tell me this was the best salmon he had ever had.

The only things I do that are not in the recipe is to 
a) sometimes I bake it in the oven with all the marinade and then thicken the liquid with a little cornstarch at the end.
b) when grilling on the BBQ I save the marinade, boil for a minute or so and then thicken with cornstarch and pour over the salmon before serving.
The marinade is just too  good not to use!

text:
Excellent recipe just as is. I made it for Christmas dinner for the first time and *risked* making it without any modifications. It is possibly the best salmon I have ever had. 

I marinated it overnight to save on time. I don't have a grill, so I packed in foil individually and baked in oven for about 18 minutes. I also made the gravy with the marinade as others suggested and that is what made this salmon over the top delicious! I put it to boil on the stove and added a bit of flour to thicken. It was lumpy but that was my fault. This will be my go-to meal for impressing company. Thank you for the recipe.

text:
I had no idea where to start with salmon and this was delicious the first time. I did add my own twist to this. As for substitutes I used McCormick's grill mates lemon pepper(has all of the listed seasonings in it), olive oil, and local honey. This is just what I had already available. Added some red pepper flakes too.
Cooking method: Cook skin up for ~1min. Flip meat and pour on some of the marinade. Finish the remaining cooking time. Use sharp spatula to cleanly separate meat from skin and plate it. The remaining skin was fairly easy to scrape off of the grill. 

I will be doing this again soon. Thanks!

Next time, I will probably cut back on both to 1/4 cup soy, 1/8 cup brwn sgr and use lemon juice and fresh ginger as other reviewers recommended. text:
Let me start by saying I've never liked salmon, but decided to give this a try since I'm often on the grill and need to augment my diet with fish.  

I followed the instructions and although I didn't care for it,  my son really loved it.  The star rating is based on his assessment since he loves fish.  

I plan to try this recipe again, but next time I'll soak the salmon in milk for 20 minutes to help remove the fishy smell.  I've recently tried that with other types of fish and it works.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2016-10-07T21:37:51.407

text:
I have made this several times now and it is truly the best marinade for salmon I have ever tasted. I ad onion powder to the seasonings, and only use Kingsford Applewood briquettes.
I place the fillets on canola oil sprayed non-stick aluminum foil up on the upper rack of my barbeque grill. It is excellent for Atlantic Salmon, but my absolute favorite is the sockeye salmon!

text:
I had a few requirements for a salmon dinner  for a get together with friends: easy to prepare, grilling outdoors, little time away from company and delicious.  This recipe hit all my requests.  I did not have any lemon pepper so I substituted lemon thyme in its place.  I was able to prepare the salmon two hrs. ahead of time and enjoy the company of friends.  I served the salmon with a sugar pea pod/potato salad which I also made ahead of time.  Sipping on white sangria (also made ahead of time) made my entertaining fun and easy.
Oh, my company wanted the salmon recipe they liked it so much.  Thanks for the recipe, it's already saved to my favorites.

text:
Fantastic!! Delicious! Quick and easy dinner which taste amazing. The  salmon ended up marinating for 4 hours instead of 2.  I grilled the salmon non-skin side down first for 4-5 minutes I then flipped the salmon and cooked it skin side down for 2-3 minutes more. This created a sweet caramelization on the salmon that my family loved, including the 3 & 5 year old. Definitely will be adding this to our dinner rotation.

text:
Okay so my husband keeps me away from the stove (for good reason,) but around here I pride myself on the grill skills.... I grill anything I can get my hands on and I'll say this much, I continuously come back to this recipe. It's crazy easy and CRAZY good! What JonLemire said about grilling the first side flesh down is spot on, although we prefer our salmon a bit less done so I'll usually do 6.5 min then flip skin down for 5.5 minutes. It also tastes ten times better when you leave it in the marinade a day or two to really soak in the flavor. A must try if you and your family like salmon. A++++

Go to recipe for salmon in the future.

datakix

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best salmon recipe I've come across on the web! I used Kerrygold unsalted butter instead of oil and cooked in a T-Fal non-stick pan on the stove top. I marinated the salmon for ~8 hrs in the fridge. As a side dish, I cooked a white potato in the pressure cooker, and added cracked black pepper and shredded cheddar cheese. Additionally, (as other reviewers have suggested) I poured the marinade in a small pot, added some cornstarch and water, let it cook for ~7 mins on med heat to make a gravy. The gravy was a bit oily, but still very good.

I absolutely will be making the recipe again.

I made this recipe. I was looking for a sweet salmon recipe. I did not have maple syrup to make a maple salmon recipe, so I tried this one. I was pleased with the taste and my family enjoyed it, as well. I will definitely make this again. The only change I made was I added some  chopped garlic to the marinade. I did not fire up the grill, so I baked it at 450 for 12 minutes and broiled for 5 minutes (like other reviewers suggested) in the remaining sauce.

text:
There is no doubt this is a good recipe.  Even my boyfriend who is new to the world of non-fried fish, and specifically salmon, really liked it.  I ended up baking it in the oven at 400 degrees for 10 minutes and then broiled it for 5 minutes.  It turned out great!  The only thing that was slightly shocking was the amount of sugar.  I think next time I'll reduce it because it seems like a lot.  I'll also make a sauce with soy sauce, a bit of brown sugar, water (or stock or orange juice), garlic, salt, pepper and cornstarch to serve over the fish.

text:
I made as directed. The soy sauce seemed somewhat overpowering, just a tad. I like the glaze-like texture from (indoor) grilling. A couple more ingredients and this recipe could seriously be restaurant, fine dining quality. I'd give it a 4 out of five rating, as is. Perhaps I may throw in a splash of bourbon and pineapple juice and serve with grilled pineapple. 

We are a family of picky eaters!!!! So don't take this lightly when I say that I'm definitely adding this recipe to my repertoire. I would strongly encourage you to give it a try.

region:

country:
None
text:
This was incredibly good and moist. I also added the seasonings to the liquid before I marinated for about four hours. I grilled them on my Weber on a grill mat ( a nonstick thin mat that keeps delicate things from sticking) along with some red bell pepper. I went skin side down for 7 minutes, flipped (skin stayed on the fish, which my wife loves) cooked for 6 more minutes. It came out very flavorful and uber moist and tender. A great way to cook salmon!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6256093.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great starting idea for salmon. I use the ingredients listed (except the water) but in natural form. So instead of lemon pepper, use squeezed lemon and pepper, instead of garlic powder, real minced garlic, etc. I use all of these ingredients to taste and the results are fantastic. Be sure to choose salmon filets of uniform thickness so they will cook evenly, and if you don't want to grill them, put them skin side down on a prepared glass oven-proof dish 6" under the broiler, cooking until the fish flakes with a fork. Great stuff :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love making this recipe whenever my roommate and I have the chance to buy salmon. It is a bit on the sweet side, so adding something to counteract that (sriracha or perhaps red paper flakes?) would probably be a great addition if you find it too sweet. I like to prep this, let it marinate for about 2 or more hours, and then throw it on a George Foreman grill for until I can see that it is still moist enough on the inside that it breaks and crumbles apart with a fork when I check if it fully cooked. This is one of the easiest/laziest way to create delicious salmon!

text:
Great recipe - very easy.  The sauce is very sweet - I may add lemon juice next time or reduce the brown sugar.  I grilled the salmon with skin side down on foil for the first 5 minutes then took the salmon off the foil (the skin stayed with the foil) and then put flesh side down on the grill for just a few minutes more which caramelized the sauce on the salmon.  Reduced the remaining sauce by boiling on the stove.  Good, just too sweet for me.

I made this with a little improv. Had no brown sugar, so I mixed white sugar and some blackstrap molasses. I cut the soy sauce down to a tablespoon and used olive oil. I also cooked it in the foil in the oven like one reviewer mentioned. I poured all of the marinade into the foil pouch. It worked out nice. Most everyone liked it and rated it 4.5 stars. text:
Great recipe for Salmon even for the non-Salmon lover like me.  Very flavorful.  I only had 1 hr. to marinade but then boiled the rest and basted during grilling.  I also took the advice of another and cooked it first skin side down on aluminum foil then when I flipped it the skin pulled right off with the foil!  The only issue I had then was that the side that was directly on the grill was sticking so might need to flip it onto another piece of foil or try a foil packet like others suggested.  My son who is 10 said we need to have this more often!

text:
I usually make blackened salmon, but I had some salmon that had been in my freezer for a while and thought that using a marinade would hide some deficiencies that freezing causes. It worked. This marinade was super easy to prepare, especially since I stuck to the recipe without any alteration in ingredients. I did, however, bake it in the oven rather than grill it. I took the advice of others and cooked it for about 12 minutes at 450 degrees, followed by a couple of minutes at broil. It came out nice and moist and flavorful. It was a nice change from the normal way I cook salmon.

text:
I have had this no fewer than 10 times since I found the recipe and it remains an awesome staple.  In the last several meals I have used a cedar plank to grill the salmon and it works much better than straight on the grill.  I added dill and cilantro to the water for soaking the plank but not sure how much it makes a difference.   soak the plank for at least two hours and then skin side down on the plank.   Tonight I added red pepper flakes to the marinade and OMGosh it was wonderful ... Provided exactly the right kick to the fish.  I will definitely use the red pepper when I can't use garlic for friends that are allergic.  thank you so much for a great base!

text:
I added a tablespoon of crushed garlic to the liquid mixture. I only had an hour for marinading but that worked ok. It seemed to emphasize the salmon more which was of high quality. I put the salmon slices in an aluminum foil wrap and drizzled a few tablespoons of the marinade on top of the salmon before sealing. The marinade was absorbed by the salmon and kept it moist. The foil meant cooking it about 10 minutes on each side on my charcoal grill. It was delicious!

text:
Love the flavor of this marinade.  Only thing I changed in the marinade is to use EVOO instead of vegetable oil.  I marinated for about 4 hours and chose the foil packet way of cooking (my first time for this).  I boiled the marinade with a teaspoon of cornstarch and just brushed that on the filets after they finished cooking.  Next time I will bake them for the 12 minutes, brush on the thickened marinade and broil for 5 minutes.  Any way you cook them you can't beat the flavor of the marinade.  It's yumbo.

text:
My wife and kids really liked it, but, as with every recipe I find on here, I made some modifications based on the reviews:

I have a family of 6 so I used 3lbs of Swai.
Also, I didn't have lemon pepper, so I added coarse ground black pepper and juiced a whole lime; I also decided to use about a teaspoon of minced garlic instead of garlic powder.

I baked them in little foil packets (and ladled in the sauce mixture into each) at 350 for 15mins, and served over white rice and topped with chopped green onions.

According to the kids, I'll be making this again soon.

text:
FANTASTIC and simple.  We love it.  I grilled half the salmon on the first day and half the second day.  The second half marinated for almost 30 hours and was even better than the first.  (Some meats don't do well with over-marination, but my fresh Coho Salmon did great.)  I always bring the fish up to room temp before I grill, so it comes uniformly up to temperature (135º).

text:
Excellent! I sprinkled the salmon with lemon juice and pepper, then marinated it with the soy sauce, brown sugar and olive oil. After 2 hours I wrapped it in tinfoil and baked for 15 minutes in the oven at 425. While baking I made a salad and thickened the sauce with cornstarch. Delicious, next time I want to make it for company, it was that good and easy. 8/17 I have tried it with lemon pepper still delicious although I couldn't marinate it that long.

text:
Really good base - and great with the changes others mentioned:  used juice of 1 lemon instead of lemon pepper, decreased soy sauce to 1/4 cup and used only 1 Tbsp olive oil.  Also did grill flesh side 1st, then flipped but would suggest re-oiling grill when flipping salmon over.  Marinating for a couple of hours really brings flavors out.  Thanks for the basic recipe.

text:
I made this recipe using swai fish...the frozen kind, so nothing fancy. It came out absolutely delicious! The only thing I did differently was 1) I baked it for about 25 minutes on 400 degrees with about 75% of the marinade drizzled on top and 2) I added green onions to the marinade (because I love green onions). They complimented the favors nicely...this a new staple for my fish recipes!!! P.S. I tried it with frozen salmon filets (sans green onions) previously...the swai turned out better.

text:
For years I have avoided salmon.. I never cared for it in restaurants and couldn't get into the smoked version. So when my hubby requested that I add salmon to our menu rotation for health reasons, I came across this recipe and made a back-up dinner for myself in case I didn't like it. I ended up eating the whole fillet - and have made salmon several times since then! I used Elizabeth's advice and baked the fillets in foil packets - they turned out perfectly! My husband has requested I make this for our next dinner party!
Thank you for a simple and delicious way to enjoy salmon!

text:
I thought it was pretty good, but a little salty, and I really didn't even use that much salt to begin with because I knew the soy sauce would be pretty salty on its own. I did add a few good squirts of lemon juice to the marinade since I didn't have any lemon pepper (along with seasoning the fillets with pepper). I also used grape seed oil instead of vegetable, and cooked on the stove top instead of a grill. Just a side note, I was making asparagus to go with this and decided to add some of the marinade to the asparagus after sauteing in butter and omg it came out so good!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/927270.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great! I cooked mine in the oven since I live in Michigan and it is January :) I marinated just as the recipe says and then place the fish on an ungreased cookie sheet lined with foil. I turned in the broiler, and while I waited for it to heat up, I started cooking the bottom on the glass top stove on high. I just placed the sheet right over the glass. Once the broiler was ready, I put the fish one the first rack directly under the broiler for about 7 minutes. I then switched the over to bake at 350 and baked on the center rack for about 20 more minutes. My filet was VERY thick, so I checked it every 5 minutes after the first 10 on bake. It was moist and wonderful! Even my 4 year old and 5 year old ate it! (the asparagus was another story :)

yes we tried it at home with my kids (9, 10, 14) and we all loved it.  prepped as instructed but left the salmon as one large fillet then sat the whole thing skin side down on foil and placed it on the grill to cook.  the foil allowed me to create a steam tent and well keep more of the flavors together.  once done your fish will pull away from the skin nicely and you through out the foil with no messy grill to clean.

text:
Simple, elegant, perfect! I wouldn't change a thing but you could easily add your own favorite herbs and spices. I used this for a Copper River salmon filet, marinating it for about 3 hours. I broiled the fish skin side down on a pre-heated pan for about 8-10 minutes. To die for!! It flavors the fish without overpowering it. Just a hint of sweetness from the brown sugar. Even though salmon is expensive (our three large servings cost $13) it's still cheaper and so much more nutritious than fast food! Including rice, veggies, and dessert, the entire meal was less than $20 for three adults!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SOOOOOO good!  I marinated the salmon on the counter for about 2 1/2 hours to bring it to room temp before cooking it.  I took other users' advice and cut the salmon into the portion sizes that I wanted and pan seared the flesh side down on med hi heat for about two minutes.  Then I used foil to wrap each piece in a glass baking dish skin side down.  Poured a little of the marinade into each foil pouch and baked the fish @ 425 for about 17 minutes til it got to the perfect doneness for me (Unless it's sashimi,  like my salmon med-well).  It was a HUGE hit!  My boyfriend isn't really a seafood guy and he devoured every bite!  Definitely will make this again!

text:
Awesome! I only had one fillet, so I just seasoned it with lemon juice and pepper (did not have lemon pepper). I made the marinade with equal parts soy sauce, brown sugar, water, and olive oil (instead of veggie oil) - I just eyeballed it with a spoon instead of measuring (SO easy!). Added a a chopped up clove of garlic to the marinade. Cooked it up on a George Forman grill, super fast, super easy, and delicious!

text:
I made this for a surprise dinner for my parents' anniversary.. I didn't have 2 hours to marinate the fish so I poked a ton of holes in the salmon fillet and immersed it in a bowl of the marinade for about 30 minutes instead. Also, the lemon-pepper we had was questionable so I just used half a capfull of lemon juice with the seasoning. I got a text message later that night from my mom demanding to know how I made that salmon, because it was the best she had ever had!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/239061.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Superb!!! I have several grilled salmon recipes, but this one has it all. It's as good as it's going to get. However, I do not use foil on the grill. I have 2 Weber charcoal grill, and cook over direct heat. If you want to "take it up a notch", soak some hickory chips in water for 30 minutes, and scatter them on the hot coals. Cover the grill, and as soon as you see some smoke put the salmon on the grill. You won't be sorry! If you have a gas grill, put the soaked chips in a foil package, poke holes in the bottom, and set the package over the spot where the gas ignites.
Review:

4

text:
So good even for leftovers! I too didn't have time for marinade, but i stuck it in the fridge flesh side down in the juice for 30 mins or so then did the foil pouch thing and it was fantastic. Had left overs so heated them up right in the oven in the same pouch and fliped them to be skin side up half way through. I put in on a nice firm bread and drizzled the remainder of the juice and had a yummy treat! The skin came off so easily, just gently used the edge of a fork. Next time i'd like to try it with pepper for a nice spicy kick

text:
This is a great simple recipe for salmon.  I think salmon tastes great on it's own so getting too fancy runs the risk of ruining it.  I've got to say, you folks who are wrapping your fish in a little foil pouch, be brave, put it on the grill, directly on the grill, a charcoal grill.  If you're going to trap it in foil why bother lighting a grill at all?  GRILL it ON the grill, it's so delicious!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I bet this is great on grilled salmon.  I read through all the reviews to see if anyone used it on their smoker, but no one did.  I tried one salmon plain and one with this marinade.  The smoke taste was too dominant - this marinade was lost.  I could barely taste the difference between plain and marinated.  So, if you're planning on smoking this, it isn't worth it.  I look forward to trying it on just grilled salmon though - the marinade has all the right stuff!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome!   I used a 2# sockeye salmon fillet that I bought frozen.  Defrosted in frig for 24 hours (in original packaging), than cut in 1/2 and marinated both halfs for 8 hours. Grilled skin side up for 7 min. (on oiled grill grate) than flipped and grilled for another 8 min.  Best salmon we have ever had.   Served 7 with a few pieces leftover for the next day.  Thanks for great recipe.

text:
An easy, quick recipe with a great flavor! All the recipes are things I had on hand. Instead of grilling though, I baked it. A genereal rule of thumb for baking salmon is bake at 400 degrees and 10 minutes for every inch of thickness. I promise you will get perfection each time!! Next time, I will skip the salt though because the soy sauce and garlic powder is plenty salty. This marinade will also go great with chicken too I think.

text:
So good and super easy!  I served this to a group of 12 ladies and was going to grill it, but it was raining so hard, I just didn't want to deal with the outside gas grill.  Instead, I sliced it into 12 individual serving size pieces and wrapped each piece in a foil pouch and baked it at 350 degrees for about 12 minutes.  The salmon was incredible!  Moist and delicious!  My ladies and my hubby told me it was the BEST salmon they had ever had!

text:
This is a fantastic recipe.  I tried it months ago, and I've been making it regularly ever since.  I've gradually made a few changes... Now I omit the garlic powder; instead, I crush a clove of garlic and add it to the marinade.  And instead of using lemon pepper, I just put a slice of lemon on the fillet as it grills, then squeeze the lemon onto the fish once it's on my plate.

text:
this recipe was delicious, fast, simple, and basically foolproof. did i mention delicious? i took the advice of the other reviewers and used the foil packet (425 for 15-16 mins, making two servings) and used olive oil in place of the vegetable oil as well. oh..and i also only let the fish marinate about 30-40 mins..ive read a few places that you shouldnt let fish marinate longer than that, it isnt the same as when you marinate meat or poultry.
it turned out amazingly tender, juicy, full of flavor, and made it seem like i had some actual skill and proficiency in the kitchen. haha.

text:
My husband and I love this recipe. I usually cook the salmon on stove top. A few drops of liquid smoke into the marinade is nice also. Right before I cook it after it comes out of the marinade I rub some pepper/coarse salt and ginger on each side. The salt helps to seer in the juices. I also use lower sodium soy sauce and Canola oil in place of vegetable oil. It is now one of our favorite dinners!

Great tasting and easy recipe with ingredients that I already had on hand.  I slightly changed it by adding garlic and green onions to the marinade.  I then baked it in the oven for 12-15 minutes and served over rice.  I garnished the salmon with sesame seeds and more green onions.  Next time, I think I will also add some dried chile flakes to add a kick to it.  Great recipe!!

text:
I use this recipe, with a little alteration, to marinate my salmon and chicken.  I use 1/4c. lemon juice, and about 1/2 tsp. of ground black pepper, instead of lemon pepper.  I also use fresh basil and whole cloves.  To make healthier, I use xylitol(natural sugar substitute derived from birch)in place of brown sugar, at almost equal equivalent.

Salmon is one of the few fish the whole family will eat so we will up our fish intake with this recipe (budget permitting).

Very nice. I made this for a BBQ I had on Canada Day. I didn't have the lemon pepper and forgot about the garlic.  I only used the soy sauce, brown sugar and 2 tbsps of olive oil.  I marinated the salmon steaks for about 45 minutes and popped them on the BBQ. They were a hit!  I served this along with grilled asparagus (tossed in olive oil, salt/pepper & a squeeze of fresh lemon), a tossed salad, brown rice and some fresh bread.  It was a nice light dinner on a really hot day.

Absolutely amazing.  So tasty.  I read on another website that to cook fish on the grill, you should have it cranked as high as possible for several minutes before putting the fish on (they said 20, but that seemed like overkill).  This is supposed to sear the fish on the outside, as opposed to drying it out.  We had this with grilled asparagus and it was to die for.

Display Name:
DEBBIE ALVAREZ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/55766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent!  I didn't have time to marinate the salmon long- I mixed all the ingredients (I used lemon garlic seasoning and kosher salt)in the bag and left the salmon sit in it for about 15-20 minutes while the grill was heating up.  Then I just basted the salmon a couple of times on each side.  I grilled it skin side down first for about 8 minutes then when I flipped the salmon the skin stayed on the grill and when it was ready we got just fish. I cooked it 7 minutes on the 2nd side.  I coated the(we use a charcoal grill) grill with both veg. oil and sprayed it with nonstick both. This was SOOOOOOOO good, we will use this recipe again.

text:
Salmon was delicious!  I used the salmon in a wrap.  I sliced my salmon into 1-inch wide strips and marinated them for about 2 hours.  I slightly changed the marinade: 3 tbsp brown sugar, 4 tbsp soya sauce, 1 tbsp dark soya sauce, 4 tbsp water, 1 tbsp olive oil.  I baked the salmon (spoon some of the marinating liquid over the salmon before placing it in the oven) at 400 degrees for about 15-20 minutes.

ORCHIDS13

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! My husband normally does not like salmon, but even he enjoyed these. Since we don't have a grill, I lined our toaster oven tray with a long piece of foil and after placing the fillets in there, lightly covered the fillets with foil and followed another reviewer's instructions to bake at 450 degrees for 12 minutes then broil for 5 minutes, and they turned out so tender. Instead of using lemon pepper, I used a little lemon juice, and I used low-sodium soy sauce, and I marinated it in the fridge for about 45 minutes instead of 2 hours since we were hungry. We also used a large salmon filet we purchased from Costco which we sliced into about six long strips. I served the filets with sauteed zuchinni and white rice I cooked with chicken broth instead of water, and it was a great meal!

text:
Followed recipe exactly, and it was excellent!  Marinated for 3 hours, & broiled it (didn't take as long to cook, so be careful!).  I put about 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, & 2 Tbsp lemon pepper on the filets before marinating.  Couldn't really taste the lemon pepper, but I'd rather not have it overpower everything else.  Lemon & lime wedges squeezed on was very tasty though.  Hubby really loved it!  He couldn't stop raving about it.  Was as good or better than restaraunt broiled salmon.  As my hubby said, this definitely is a keeper!  Thanks Tina!

Wonderful, wonderful recipe. However, do not add lemon juice and pepper(like I did) instead of lemon-pepper seasoning. A nutritionist told me that lemon juice dries out fish. Therefore mine was a little dry but otherwise fabulous. If you love salmon-even if you don't love salmon, try this recipe!
